PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES 
Subpart A - GENERAL ORDINANCES 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The provisions embraced in this and the following chapters, articles and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Hapeville, Georgia," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1959, § 1-1; Code 1981, § 1-1-1) 
Sec. 1-1-2. - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
(1)  City . The words "the city" or "this city" shall be construed as if the words "of Hapeville, Georgia" followed the word city, and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
(2)  City council . The words "city council" or "the council" shall be construed to mean the governing body of the City of Hapeville, Georgia, consisting of a mayor, council members and an alderman. 
(3)  Computation of time . Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done, a certain length of time before any proceedings shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall not be counted. 
(4)  County . The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Fulton, Georgia. 
(5)  Gender . A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
(6)  Interpretation . In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
(7)  Name or title of officer, board, commission or agency . The name or title of any officer, board, commission or agency, when appearing alone herein, shall be construed as if the words "of Hapeville, Georgia" followed it. 
(8)  Number . A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
(9)  Oath . The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
(10)  Or, and . The word "or" may be read as the word "and," and the word "and" may be read as the word "or," if the sense requires it. 
(11)  Owner . The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
(12)  Person . The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
(13)  Personal property [The words "personal property"] include every species of property except real property. 
(14)  State . The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Georgia. 
(15)  Time . Words used in the present or past tense include the future as well as the present or past. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-2) 
Sec. 1-1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted, unless expressly so provided. 
(Code 1959, § 1-3; Code 1981, § 1-1-3) 
Sec. 1-1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1959, § 1-4; Code 1981, § 1-1-4) 
Sec. 1-1-5. - Severability. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that all sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are or were, upon their enactment, believed by the mayor and council to be fully valid, enforceable and constitutional. 
(b)  It is hereby declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, each and every section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is severable from every other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code. It is hereby further declared to be the intention of the mayor and council that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, no section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is mutually dependent upon any other section, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code. 
(c)  In the event that any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall, for any reason whatsoever, be declared invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, it is the express intent of the mayor and council that such invalidity, unconstitutionality or unenforceability shall, to the greatest extent allowed by law, not render invalid, unconstitutional or otherwise unenforceable any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of the Code and that, to the greatest extent allowed by law, all remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of the Code shall remain valid, constitutional, enforceable, and of full force and effect. 
(Code 1959, § 1-5; Code 1981, § 1-1-5; Ord. No. 2000-23, § 1, 10-3-2000) 
Sec. 1-1-6. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein. In the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code of Ordinances by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code. 
(c)  All sections, divisions, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-6; Ord. No. 99-04, § 1, 3-2-1999; Ord. No. 2001-19, § 1, 12-4-2001) 
Sec. 1-1-7. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever, except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the mayor and council, which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 hereof. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-7) 
Sec. 1-1-8. - General penalty; continuing violations; adjudging fines and imprisonments. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any provision of this Code and where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any provision of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months or by both such fine and imprisonment. Such penalty may include, in the discretion of the municipal court judge, sentencing offenders to work in a work gang on the public streets or on such public works as the city may employ the work gang. Each day any violation of any provision of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1981, § 1-1-8) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE 2. - MAYOR AND COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-2-1. - Council meetings; time, calling special meetings, rules of order. 
(a)  The mayor and council shall meet on the first Tuesday in each month at 6:00 p.m. Eastern Time (ET) and continue in session from day to day in their discretion. 
(b)  Special meetings may be called by the mayor or any three members of the council at any time when deemed necessary. 
(c)  The mayor and two members of council, or the alderman-at-large and two council members, shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. A less number may adjourn from time to time and compel attendance of absentees. 
(d)  In the absence of the mayor, the alderman-at-large, or, if absent, any member of the council may be chosen to take the chair at the hour appointed for any meeting. 
(e)  Every committee shall report at the succeeding meeting on all matters referred to them, or show good cause why such report is not made. 
(f)  A majority of the council shall govern. The mayor or presiding officer shall vote only in case of a tie. 
(g)  Any member of the council may call for the "yeas" and "nays" on any question, and the vote so taken shall be recorded in the minutes. 
(h)  The mayor or presiding officer shall enforce parliamentary rules so far as they are applicable to such a legislative body and do not conflict with the rules adopted. "Robert's Rules of Order" shall be regarded as authority on parliamentary laws. 
(i)  Any additional rule or rules may be made from time to time, but no rule shall be altered or suspended without consent of 2/3 of the members present. 
(Code 1959, § 2-1; Code 1981, § 2-1-1; Ord. No. 2018-13 , § 1, 10-2-2018) 
Sec. 2-2-2. - Same; mayor, duties. 
    The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the council, and it shall be his duty to see that all laws and ordinances are enforced in a legal manner, and that the other officers of the city perform their duties properly including the making of such official bonds as are required, of which he shall be the custodian. All ordinances as passed by the council shall be approved and signed by the mayor within four days, or he shall file his dissent as provided under section 2-405 of the charter. 
(Code 1959, § 2-2; Code 1981, § 2-1-2) 
Sec. 2-2-3. - Public meetings. 
    All meetings of the mayor and council or any board, commission, or other body of the city shall be open to the public, except that any meeting or portion thereof may be closed to the public in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 50-14-1 et seq. and as amended hereafter. 
(Code 1981, § 2-1-3; Ord. No. 2004-22, § 1, 12-21-2004) 
Sec. 2-2-4. - Performance bonds of employees. 
    The mayor and council may, by resolution, require a bond of any employee of the city conditioned on faithful performance, payable to the city in an amount set in the resolution. Premiums thereon are to be paid by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 2-1-4) 
Sec. 2-2-5. - Rules and procedures of mayor and council. 
(a)  Ordinances. All ordinances passed by the council may, at a minimum, contain the following items: 
(1)  Ordinance number; 
(2)  Adoption date; 
(3)  Codification clause; 
(4)  Severability clause; 
(5)  Signature of mayor; 
(6)  Attestation by city manager, chief administrator, city administrator, director of finance and administration or city clerk as applicable; and 
(7)  Approval of city attorney as to form. 
(b)  Recording of ordinances. All ordinances shall be recorded in a separate book for that purpose, and the book shall bear the title "Ordinances of the City of Hapeville, Georgia." 
(c)  Mayor's meeting responsibilities. The mayor shall take the chair at the hour appointed and call the members of the council to order. He or she shall preserve order and decorum, decide all questions of order, unless appealed to the council, and appoint all committees. In the absence of the mayor, the mayor pro tem is vested with like powers. If the mayor is compelled to partake in discussion, the mayor shall have the right to do so. 
(d)  Order of meetings. The business of all regular meetings of the council may be transacted in the following order: 
(1)  Call to order; 
(2)  Roll call; 
(3)  Welcome; 
a.  Pledge of Allegiance; 
b.  Invocation. 
(4)  Presentations; 
(5)  Public hearing; 
a.  Public comments will be received pursuant to subsection (e) of this section. 
(6)  Questions on agenda items; 
(7)  Consent agenda; 
(8)  Old business; 
(9)  New business; 
(10)  Committee reports; 
(11)  Public comments; and 
(12)  Adjournment. 
    The mayor and council, by a vote of a majority of the members present, may suspend the rules and change the order of business. 
(e)  Public hearings. Public hearings at meetings of the city shall be conducted in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Staff recommendation. First, the staff will present its recommendation to mayor and council including dispositive considerations in making their recommendation. 
(2)  Applicant's presentation. After the staff recommendation, the applicant shall present their application by first identifying themselves and then providing any pertinent facts or documentation in support of their applications. 
(3)  Public comments. Comments from members of the public regarding the current topic on the floor, beginning with comments in opposition, followed by comments in support, with a follow-up from the applicant to address issues raised by previous commenters. If the commenter begins to stray away from the specific agenda item, the mayor may limit the commentary. Once an agenda item has passed, the mayor and council will not hear any comments regarding the specific agenda item, unless reserved for general comment session at the end of the meeting. 
a.  Time limitations. Ten minutes will be provided for discussion per agenda item, in addition to a total of ten minutes for comments by those in opposition and ten minutes for comments by those in support. 
(f)  Zoning hearings. The following rules of procedures shall govern any public hearing regarding zoning request or determination before the mayor and council: 
(1)  Each applicant shall appear before the council, identify himself/herself by name, address and whether or not applicant is owner or agent for owner. 
(2)  Each applicant or other interested party who provides the council with documents shall have each document numbered and shall identify each document and each such document submitted shall be made a part of the official record of the hearing. 
(3)  Each applicant shall have ten minutes to present facts pertinent to the application. An applicant may have additional time to address the council if the applicant notifies the city clerk prior to the start of the public hearing that applicant needs additional time. The council may grant additional time to the applicant at their own discretion. 
(4)  All people in opposition to the rezoning of property and amendment to the zoning ordinance shall have ten minutes to address the council and shall provide the city clerk with name and address; however, the total time for all interested parties in opposition shall be 30 minutes unless the applicant requests for additional time, in which case the total time shall not exceed 40 minutes. 
(5)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the council shall make a final decision at its next regular public meeting and direct the community development department to notify the applicant in writing of the council's decision. The written notification shall immediately be entered on the minutes and made a part of the record on the date that written notification is given to the applicant. 
(6)  Any aggrieved party shall have 30 days from the date of written notification to file an appeal from the council's decision with the superior court. 
(g)  Evidentiary hearings. The following rules of procedure shall govern all other evidentiary hearings not covered above: 
(1)  Each proponent shall appear before the council, identify himself/herself by name, and present the issue to the council. 
(2)  Each proponent who provides the council with documents shall have each document numbered and shall identify each document and each such document submitted shall be made a part of the official record of the hearing. Certified copies of documents shall be provided to the council, if applicable. 
(3)  Each proponent shall have ten minutes to present facts pertinent to the issue. The proponent may have additional time to address the council if the proponent notifies the city clerk prior to the start of the public hearing that proponent needs additional time. The council may grant additional time to the proponent at their own discretion. 
(4)  All people in opposition to the issue shall have ten minutes to address the council and shall provide the city clerk with name and address; however, the total time for all interested parties in opposition shall be 30 minutes unless the proponent requests for additional time, in which case the total time shall not exceed 40 minutes. 
(5)  The proponent shall be granted an additional five minutes to rebut any arguments made in opposition but submitting additional evidence. 
(6)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the council shall make a final decision and during its next regular public meeting, shall notify the proponent in writing of the council's decision. The written notification shall immediately be entered on the minutes and made a part of the record on the date that written notification is given to the proponent. 
(7)  Any aggrieved party shall have 30 days from the date of written notification to file an appeal from the council's decision with the superior court. 
(h)  General comments. General comments regarding items not listed on the agenda will be made available before the adjournment of the meeting. Prior to the commencement of each meeting during which there will be a general comment portion, members of the public wishing to speak shall sign in with the city clerk and shall provide their name and the topic upon which they wish to speak; this will be known as the registered comments session. Members of the public that failed to sign in with the city clerk and have not identified themselves or the topic they wish to speak about will have the opportunity to speak during the unregistered comment session. 
(1)  Time limitations (registered comment session). Each member of the public, who signed up with the city clerk prior to the commencement of the meeting, wishing to address the mayor or council during the general comment session shall have a total of three minutes during which he/she may address the mayor or council. Such time shall not be extended unless approved by a majority of the council members present. The three-minute time limit shall not be extended by any dialogue with or comments by council or the mayor. The entire general comment session for registered comments shall not last more than 15 minutes unless extended by council. 
(2)  Time limitations (unregistered comment session). Each member of the public, who failed to sign up with the city clerk prior to the commencement of the meeting, wishing to address the mayor or council during the general comment session shall have a total of two minutes during which he/she may address the mayor or council. Such time shall not be extended unless approved by a majority of the council members present. The two-minute time limit shall not be extended by any dialogue with or comments by council or the mayor. The entire general comment session for unregistered comments shall not last more than ten minutes unless extended by council. 
(3)  General comment content. No member of the public shall be permitted to make personal, impertinent, slanderous or profane remarks to the mayor or any council member. Mayor and council meetings serve the purpose of conducting city business and are not a forum for the unlimited expression of opinion. The mayor reserves the right to limit comments to matters germane to city business and may refer speakers to the city manager or other staff for resolution. 
(i)  Recording in minutes. All of the following shall be recorded in the ordinance and minute books of the mayor and council: 
(1)  All motions, except for adjournment; 
(2)  All resolutions; 
(3)  All information required by the laws of the United States and of this state; 
(4)  The motion, number and title by which new ordinances are introduced; 
(5)  The "yeas" and "nays" shall be recorded whenever required by one or more members; and 
(6)  All other information which the mayor and council may direct. 
(j)  Appointments. All appointments shall be by ballot. 
(k)  Council members. During mayor and city council meetings, the council members shall not: 
(1)  Interrupt anyone who has the floor; 
(2)  Represent the personal opinion and beliefs; 
(3)  Refuse to recognize the validity of the actions approved by a majority vote of the board; and 
(4)  Text and send messages to other council members. 
(l)  Addressing presiding officer. During city council meetings, each council member, when speaking on a particular item, shall address the presiding officer. 
(m)  Robert's Rules of Parliamentary Order. Robert's Rules of Parliamentary Order shall be regarded as supplementary guidelines for the proceedings of the council insofar as the same are applicable, and do not conflict with city ordinances. 
(n)  Recording of meeting. At all such meetings of the mayor and council or meetings of the council, the deliberations of said meeting and actions taken may be recorded by the use of magnetic tapes. Upon the minutes being edited and reduced to writing, the magnetic tapes so used may then be erased or destroyed. 
(Code 1981, § 2-1-5; Ord. No. 88-1, 4-5-1988; Ord. No. 99-04, § 2, 3-2-1999; Ord. No. 2001-19, § 2, 12-4-2001; Ord. No. 2018-14 , § 1, 11-6-2018) 
Sec. 2-2-6. - Committees. 
    There are hereby established the following standing committees: 
(1)  Administration and finance; 
(2)  Police, fire, and ordinances; 
(3)  Public service; 
(4)  Recreation, parks, buildings, and grounds; and 
(5)  Economic development. 
(Ord. No. 2004-03, § 1, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-2-7. - Compensation. 
    The compensation paid to the mayor and council of the city shall be: 
(1)  Mayor, per year ..... $ 8,400.00. 
(2)  Councilpersons, per year .....   7,800.00. 
(Ord. No. 2001-13, § 1, 6-5-2001) 
Sec. 2-2-8. - Waiving of late fees. 
    All late fees assessed under the Code of the city may be waived, upon an applicant's showing of good cause, by a vote of mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 2015-03 , § 1, 3-17-2015) 
ARTICLE 3. - ELECTIONS 

Sec. 2-3-1. - Election officials. 
    The mayor and council shall by resolution annually appoint a municipal election superintendent, election manager, registrars, absentee ballot clerk and any other officials as are necessary, all of whom shall exercise those powers and duties set forth in O.C.G.A. chapter 34A-3 and other applicable provisions of the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(Code 1981, § 2-2-1) 
State Law reference- O.C.G.A. §§ 34A-302, 34A-401, 34A-502, 34A-1109(b), 34A-1117 and 34A-1304. 
Sec. 2-3-2. - Expenses. 
(a)  The election superintendent is authorized to incur expenses in the preparation and conduct of an election including the cost of purchasing identification badges for poll officers, the printing of ballots, voters certificates and the purchasing of all other supplies necessary for the conduct of the election. The superintendent is further authorized to incur all necessary expenses to provide voting booths for the proper conduct of all elections. 
(b)  As an alternative, the mayor and council may contract with the county to perform the duties and responsibilities of holding and conducting elections in the city as provided in O.C.G.A. § 21-3-10. 
(Code 1959, § 8-2; Code 1981, § 2-2-2; Ord. No. 91-14, 7-2-1991) 
Sec. 2-3-3. - Election district and polling places. 
    All of the area within the city shall constitute one voting district. Voters shall in all cases vote at the address known by the present system of numbering buildings in the county as 3444 North Fulton Avenue. The superintendent shall cause the polling place to be provided with sufficient light and heat. 
(Code 1959, § 8-3; Code 1981, § 2-2-3; Ord. No. 91-14, 7-2-1991) 
Sec. 2-3-4. - Registration of electors. 
    The city elects to use the county registration list and Fulton County on a mutual basis with the city shall deliver such registration list not less than 14 days before any election is to be held so that a designee may check such list for accuracy of the list and to challenge the unqualified. 
(Code 1959, § 8-4; Code 1981, § 2-2-4) 
Sec. 2-3-5. - Nomination of candidates. 
(a)  In the case of a general election, the period for qualification of candidates shall be no less than three days and no more than five days and shall commence no earlier than 8:30 a.m. on the last Monday in August immediately preceding the general election and shall end no later than 4:30 p.m. on the following Friday. In the case of a special election, the qualifying period shall commence no earlier than the date of call and shall end no later than 25 days prior to the election. 
(b)  In the case of a candidate seeking one of two or more public offices each having the same title and to be filled at the same election by the vote of the same electors, such candidate shall designate the specific office by naming the incumbent. Such designation shall be entered on the ballot in such manner that in the ensuing election such candidate shall only oppose the other candidate or candidates, if any, designating the same specific office. 
(Code 1959, § 8-6; Code 1981, § 2-2-5; Ord. No. 93-16, 10-5-1993; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 1, 12-1-2009) 
Sec. 2-3-6. - Qualification fees. 
    Qualification fees for candidates seeking the office of mayor or council member shall be three percent of the annual compensation of those respective offices. The fee shall be paid to the municipal election superintendent at the time a candidate files his notice of candidacy. 
(Code 1981, § 2-2-6) 
State Law reference- Three percent limitation on qualifying fees, O.C.G.A. § 34A-904. 
Sec. 2-3-7. - Nonpartisan elections. 
    All elections held for the purpose of filling municipal offices in the city shall be nonpartisan and no political party shall conduct primaries for the purpose of nominating candidates for such municipal election. 
(Code 1959, § 8-8; Code 1981, § 2-2-7) 
Sec. 2-3-8. - Notice of candidacy. 
    Each candidate desiring to have his name placed on the ballot for an office to be filled in a municipal election shall file notice of candidacy as is provided in section 34A-901 of the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(Code 1959, § 8-9; Code 1981, § 2-2-8) 
Sec. 2-3-9. - Absentee ballots. 
    Absentee ballots shall be used in all municipal elections. The use of absentee ballots shall be governed by chapter 34A-13 of the Georgia Municipal Election Code. 
(Code 1959, § 8-10; Code 1981, § 2-2-9) 
Sec. 2-3-10. - Vote required for election. 
    A candidate for municipal office may be elected in a general or special election by receiving a plurality of the votes cast to fill such public office. 
(Code 1959, § 8-11; Code 1981, § 2-2-10) 
Sec. 2-3-11. - Contested elections. 
(a)  A contest case governed by the provisions of this section shall be determined in the county in which the city hall is located. 
(b)  Any person who was a candidate in an election or any aggrieved elector may be permitted to contest the election of any candidate upon the following grounds: 
(1)  Malconduct, fraud or irregularity by any election official sufficient to change or place in doubt the results. 
(2)  Ineligibility of the defendant for the office in dispute. 
(3)  Illegal votes received or legal votes rejected sufficient to change or place in doubt the results. 
(4)  An error in counting the votes or declaring the result of an election, if such error would change the result. 
(5)  Any other cause which shows that another was the person legally elected. 
(6)  A petition to contest the general or special election shall be filed with the city clerk within five days after the results of an election are certified to the governing body of the city. A hearing shall then be set before the governing body. Written notice shall be given to all affected candidates by the governing body of the city. The notice shall state the time and place of the hearing and shall contain a copy of the petition of contest. The hearing will take place not more than 15 days nor less than five days after service of the contest notice upon the elected candidates. 
(c)  The governing body shall have the authority to examine the qualifications of electors concerning a right to vote or a recount of ballots, examine the registration list and perform such acts and conduct such examinations as may be deemed necessary to determine the validity of a contest of an election. 
(d)  The final determination of the governing body of the city may be appealed to the superior court in the manner of appeal from the judge of probate, except that such appeal shall be made within ten days after determination of the contest by the mayor and council by the issuance of an order so signifying. 
(Code 1959, § 8-12; Code 1981, § 2-2-11) 
Sec. 2-3-12. - Composition of legislative body. 
    There shall be one council member from each ward, one council member from the city at large, one alderman from the city at large and mayor for the city at large, which shall comprise the legislative body of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-13; Code 1981, § 2-2-12) 
Sec. 2-3-13. - Council member's residence in wards. 
    Any candidate for council member from any ward shall have been a resident of the ward for at least 30 days before qualification as a candidate for council member. 
(Code 1959, § 8-14; Code 1981, § 2-2-13) 
Sec. 2-3-14. - Election dates. 
    The election for mayor and council member and alderman-at-large shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November as is provided in section 38 of the Charter of the city. Special elections to fill vacancies shall be held at such times as shall be determined by the mayor and council in accordance with section 41 of the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-15; Code 1981, § 2-2-14) 
Sec. 2-3-15. - Opening and closing of polls. 
    The polls in such elections shall be open at 7:00 a.m. and remain open until 7:00 p.m., but the mayor and council are authorized to fix the time of holding elections, including the time of opening and closing the polls as provided by section 38 of the Charter of the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-16; Code 1981, § 2-2-15) 
Sec. 2-3-16. - Notice of elections. 
    The city clerk shall give at least 15 days' notice of each election by posting the same on the door of the entrance to the city hall. In the case of a special election, the city clerk shall give ten days notice of the election by posting a notice of the same on the door of the entrance of the city hall. 
(Code 1959, § 8-17; Code 1981, § 2-2-16) 
Sec. 2-3-17. - Working for candidate near voting place. 
    On any election date, no person shall be allowed to participate in campaigning activities for any candidate within 300 feet of any voting place in the city. 
(Code 1959, § 8-19; Code 1981, § 2-2-17) 
Sec. 2-3-18. - Wards of the city. 
    The city is hereby divided into two wards. 
(Code 1959, § 8-20; Code 1981, § 2-2-18) 
Sec. 2-3-19. - First ward description. 
    The First ward is comprised of that territory south of the Central of Georgia Railway right-of-way running through the city and west of the centerline of Stewart Avenue. 
(Code 1959, § 8-21; Code 1981, § 2-2-19) 
Sec. 2-3-20. - Second ward description. 
    The Second ward is comprised of all the territory lying north of the Central of Georgia Railway right-of-way and east of the centerline of Stewart Avenue. 
(Code 1959, § 8-22; Code 1981, § 2-2-20) 
Sec. 2-3-21. - Terms of present officers. 
    All present and future elected officers of the city shall hold their offices until the expiration of the term for which they shall have been elected, and until their successors are elected and qualified, except as otherwise provided. 
(Code 1981, § 2-2-21; Ord. No. 88-6, 12-6-1988) 
ARTICLE 4. - ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS 
DIVISION 1. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR/CITY MANAGER 

Sec. 2-4-1. - Responsibilities delegated. 
    Any duties which were previously performed by or delegated to the city clerk or the director of finance and administration pursuant to the this Code shall hereinafter be performed by or delegated to the city administrator; and in all instances wherein the terms "city clerk" or "director of finance and administration" are used in this code, they shall hereinafter be construed to refer to the city administrator and/or city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-3; Ord. No. 84-5, 7-3-1984) 
Secs. 2-4-2-2-4-20. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY CLERK 

Sec. 2-4-21. - Duties. 
    In addition to the duties of the city clerk under the city charter, the city clerk shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To receive all applications or petitions made to the city and transmit them to the mayor for presentation to the council at the meeting of council next succeeding the receipt thereof; 
(2)  To be the custodian of the city seal and affix its impression on documents whenever required; 
(3)  To carefully preserve the codes, records and documents belonging to the city which are not assigned to the custody of some other office, and to maintain a proper index to all records and documents so that ready access thereto and use thereof may be had; 
(4)  To issue warrants, summons, receipts, executions or other processes of the city; and 
(5)  To perform any other duties as may be required by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-11) 
Secs. 2-4-22-2-4-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-4-31. - Powers and duties. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal advisor and counsel of the city and in that capacity shall: 
(1)  Advise the mayor and council upon legal questions arising in the conduct of city business; 
(2)  Prepare ordinances and resolutions when so requested by the mayor and council or any committee thereof; 
(3)  Render official opinions upon any legal matter or question submitted by the mayor and council; 
(4)  Attend meetings of the mayor and council as it may require; 
(5)  Prepare for execution contracts and instruments to which the city is a party when so requested and approve, as to form, all bonds and city contracts; 
(6)  Defend or institute any legal proceedings when requested by the mayor and council; and 
(7)  Render such other legal services as may be required by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-3-21) 
ARTICLE 5. - DEPARTMENTS, BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS 

Sec. 2-5-1. - Departments created. 
    The following departments of the city are hereby created: 
(1)  Administration and finance; 
(2)  Police; 
(3)  Fire; 
(4)  Public services, also known interchangeably as "community service"; 
(5)  Recreation, parks, buildings, and grounds; and 
(6)  Economic development. 
(Code 1981, § 2-4-1; Ord. No. 84-7, 8-7-1984; Ord. No. 91-6, 3-5-1991; Ord. No. 93-4, 1-5-1993; Ord. No. 94-28, 11-1-1994; Ord. No. 2004-03, § 2, 5-4-2004) 
Sec. 2-5-2. - Functions of departments. 
    The departments of the city shall perform such functions and duties as required by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-4-2) 
Sec. 2-5-3. - Boards and commissions created. 
(a)  The following boards and commissions of the city are hereby created: 
(1)  Personnel board; 
(2)  Pensions and retirement board; 
(3)  Planning commission; and 
(4)  Appeals board. 
(b)  Compensation for members of city boards and commissions shall be as fixed from time to time by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-4-3; Ord. No. 93-1, 1-5-1993) 
Editor's note- A development authority was created for the city by Resolution No. 79-2, adopted July 3, 1979, with members appointed by Resolution No. 79-3, adopted Oct. 11, 1979. 
Sec. 2-5-4. - Tenure of department heads. 
    All department heads shall serve at the will of the mayor and council and are dischargeable with or without cause. However, a majority vote of all members of the council including the mayor shall be required for the separation of a department head. 
(Code 1981, § 2-4-4; Ord. No. 94-31, 11-1-1994; Ord. No. 2000-09, § 3, 3-7-2000) 
ARTICLE 6. - CODE OF ETHICS 

Sec. 2-6-1. - Intent. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. The proper operation of democratic government requires that the mayor and council, city committees, boards, panels, public officials and city employees be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is established a code of ethics for all officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid. The purpose of this code is to establish ethical standards of conduct for all officials and employees by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interests of the city and by directing disclosure by such officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the city. The provisions and purpose of this code of ethics and such rules and regulations as may be established are declared to be in the best interests of the city. This code of ethics shall apply to all officials, employees and members of boards and commissions, task forces, panels, and authorities of the city. 
(b)  Responsibilities of public office. Public officials and employees are agents of public purpose and hold office for the benefit of the public. They are bound to uphold the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the state and to carry out impartially the laws of the nation, state and municipality, and thus to foster respect for all government. They are bound to observe in their official acts the highest standards of morality and to discharge faithfully the duties of their office, regardless of personal considerations, recognizing that the public interest must be their primary concern. 
(c)  Procurement of qualified leaders. It is also essential to the proper operation of government that those best qualified be encouraged to serve the government. Accordingly, legal safeguards against conflicts of interest must be so designed as not unnecessarily or unreasonably to impede the recruitment and retention by the city of those men and women who are best qualified to serve. An essential principle underlying the staffing of our government structure is that its elected officials and employees should not be denied the opportunity, available to all other citizens, to acquire and retain private economic and other interests, except where conflicts with the responsibility of such elected officials and employees to the public cannot be avoided. 
(d)  Dedicated service. 
(1)  All officials and employees of the municipality should be loyal to the objectives expressed by the electorate and the programs developed to attain those objectives. Appointed officials and employees should adhere to the rules of work and performance established as the standard for their positions by the appropriate authority. 
(2)  Officials and employees should not exceed their authority or breach the law or ask others to do so, and they should work in full cooperation with other public officials and employees unless prohibited from so doing by law or by the officially recognized confidential nature of their work. 
(e)  Distribution of code. The city administrator is authorized and directed to have such number of said code of ethics printed as in his or her discretion will be sufficient for distribution to the officials, employees and board, panel, task forces, authorities, and commission members, as well as having copies available at the city hall for citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-1), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, only the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    City official or official, unless otherwise expressly defined, means the mayor, members of the city council, municipal court judges, the director of finance and administration, or other city manager or city administrator, city clerk, department heads, or member of city boards or commissions. Panels, committees, tax collector, city accountant, and city employees regardless of their employment category, whether such person is appointed salaried, hired or elected. "City official," unless otherwise expressly defined, includes individuals appointed by the mayor and city council to all city commissions, committees, boards, task forces, panels, authorities, or other city bodies unless specifically exempted from this section by the city council. 
    Complaint means a written sworn statement filed with the mayor, city attorney, or board of ethics containing specific allegations of misconduct by a city official filed within six months of discovery of the alleged misconduct. 
    Decision means any ordinance, resolution, contract, franchise, formal action or other matter voted on by the mayor and council or other city board or commission, as well as the discussions or deliberations of the council, board, or commission which can or may lead to a vote or formal action by that body. 
    Discretionary authority means the power to exercise any judgment in a decision or action. 
    Employee shall be any person who is a full-time, part-time, temporary, or emergency employee of the city. 
    Entity means a sole proprietorship, partnership, limited partnership, firm, corporation, professional corporation, holding company, joint stock company, receivership, trust or any other entity recognized by law through which business may be conducted. 
    Immediate family means spouse, mother or stepmother, father or stepfather, grandfather or stepgrandfather, grandmother or stepgrandmother, father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother or stepbrother, sister or stepsister, son or stepson, daughter or stepdaughter, of any city official. 
    Incidental interest means an interest held by a person, entity or property which is not a substantial interest and which has insignificant value. 
    Interest means any direct pecuniary benefit, which is not a remote or incidental interest held by or accruing to a city official as a result of a contract or transaction that is or may be the subject of an official act or action by or with the city. A city official shall be deemed to have an interest in transactions involving: 
(1)  Any person in the member's immediate family; 
(2)  Any entity with whom a contractual relationship exists whereby the official may receive any payment or other benefits unless the official receiving a benefit for goods or services in the normal course of business for which the official has paid a commercially reasonable rate; 
(3)  Any business in which the official is a director, officer, employee, agent, or shareholder, except as otherwise provided herein; or 
(4)  Any person of whom the official is a creditor, whether secured or unsecured. 
    Remote interest means an interest of a person or entity, including a city official, who would be affected in the same way as the general public, i.e., interest of a city council member in the property tax rate, general city fees, city utility charges, or a comprehensive zoning ordinance or similar decisions is incidental to the extent that the council member would be affected in common with the general public. 
    Substantial interest means a known interest, of a city official either directly or through a member of their immediate family, in another person or entity where: (1) the interest is ownership of five percent or more of the voting stock, shares or equity or market value of the entity; or (2) funds received by the person from the other person or entity either during the previous 12 months or the previous calendar year equaled or exceeded $5,000.00 in salary, bonuses, commissions or professional fees or $5,000.00 in payment for goods, products or non-professional services, or ten percent of the recipient's gross income during that period, whichever is less; (3) the person serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors or other governing board of a for-profit entity other than a corporate entity owned or created by the city council; or (4) the person is a creditor, debtor, or guarantor of the other person or entity in an amount of $5,000.00 or more. Substantial interest in real property means an interest in real property, which is an equitable or legal ownership interest, with a market value of $5,000.00 or more. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-2), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-3. - Standards of conduct. 
(a)  No city official shall: 
(1)  Give a reasonable basis for the impression by acts or omissions that any person can improperly influence him/her or unduly enjoy his/her favor in the performance of official acts; 
(2)  Draw per diem or expense monies from the city to attend a seminar, convention, or conference and then fail to attend the seminar, convention, or conference without refunding the pro-rata unused per diem or expense monies to the city; 
(3)  Directly or indirectly request, exact, receive, or agree to receive a gift, loan, favor, promise, or thing of value for him/herself or another person if it could reasonably be considered to influence the member in the discharge of official duties; 
(4)  Disclose or otherwise use confidential information acquired by virtue of his/her official position for his/her or another person's private gain; 
(5)  Engage in, accept employment with, or render services for any private business or professional activity when such employment or rendering of services is adverse to and incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties; 
(6)  Engage in any activity or transaction that is prohibited by law now existing or hereafter enacted which is applicable to him/her by virtue of being a city official; 
(7)  Use his/her position to request or require an employee to: 
a.  Do clerical work on behalf of the official's family, business, social, church or fraternal interest when such work is not furthering the city's interest; 
b.  Perform any work outside the employee's normal course of municipal employment; 
c.  Purchase goods or services to be used for personal, business, or political purposes; and 
d.  Work for the official personally without paying the employee just compensation; 
(8)  Use government property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor shall he/she direct employees to use such property for any purposes other than those officially approved; 
(9)  Use his/her position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to himself/herself or persons having an interest; 
(10)  Enter into any contract involving services or property with any city official or with a business in which a city official has an interest. This section shall not apply in the case of: 
a.  The designation of a bank or trust company as a depository for city funds; 
b.  The borrowing of funds from any bank or lending institution, which offers the lowest available rate of interest in the community for such loan; 
c.  Contracts entered into in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-10-6; 
d.  Contracts entered into under circumstances that constitute an emergency situation, provided that the mayor prepares a written record explaining the emergency; 
e.  Contracts or business activities entered into with a city official, or with a business in which business city official has an interest, provided that such contract or activity is the result of a competitive bid, disclosure of the nature of such official's interest is made prior to the time any bid is submitted, and a waiver of the prohibition contemplated by this section is issued by the city administrator following disclosure and reporting to the mayor and council; and 
f.  Business activities solely between city officials completely unrelated to city affairs or city business. 
(b)  The city shall not enter into any contract with any person or business represented by such person, who has been within the preceding 12-month period a city official, unless the contract is awarded by a competitive bid or a committee selection process; 
(c)  Subsection (a)(3) above shall not apply in the case of: 
(1)  An occasional non-pecuniary gift of insignificant value; 
(2)  An award publicly presented in recognition of public service; 
(3)  A commercially reasonable loan or other financial transaction made in the ordinary course of business by an institution or individual authorized by the laws of the state to engage in the making of such a loan or financial transaction; and 
(4)  Campaign contributions made and reported in accordance with state law. 
(d)  Subsection (a)(5) of this section shall not apply to a city official who is a licensed professional and appears on behalf of any applicant in such professional capacity so long as disclosures required by section 2-6-4 are made to the board of ethics or chairperson of the body before which the professional is appearing 30 days prior to any action being taken, and the city official is associated with the project at the time the initial application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-3), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-4. - Disclosure of conflicts of interest. 
    A city official who has an interest or a substantial interest that he/she has reason to believe may be affected by his her official acts or actions or by the official acts or actions of city officials shall disclose the precise nature of such interest or substantial interest by written or verbal statement made in a public meeting no more than 30 days, but at least prior to the matter being heard by a body who will be taking official action on a matter affecting such interest and the city official will abstain from discussion and voting regarding the matter. An elected city official shall disclose the nature of any interest or substantial interest he/she has at the time such matter is presented to mayor and council or other considering body for discussion. Such written or verbal statements shall be recorded into the minutes of the meeting, and thus become part of the public record. Following any disclosure made pursuant to this section, the city official shall refrain from all ex-parte communications with other members regarding the application in which he/she has an interest or substantial interest. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-4), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-5. - Disqualification. 
    A city official shall disqualify himself/herself from participating in any official act or action of the city which results in a pecuniary benefit to the member or a business or activity in which he/she has an interest or substantial interest, when such benefit is not available to the public at large. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-5), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-6. - Proprietorship of creations. 
    All plans, designs, reports, specifications, drawings, devices, inventions, and other items produced or created by employees during working hours or through the use of the city's facilities or equipment or at the request of the city shall be and become the sole property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-6), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-7. - Political activity. 
(a)  No person employed by the city shall either publicly or otherwise hold himself or herself out as a candidate in any city election while employed with the city. 
(b)  City employees shall not take part in any political management or political campaigns for election of mayor or any member of the city council during any period of time for which he/she is expected to perform work or receive compensation from the city. 
(c)  No employee, official or other person shall solicit, orally or by letter, or be in any other manner concerned in obtaining any assessments, contributions, or services for any political party from any employee during their hours of duty, service, or work with the city. 
(d)  Employees shall not represent the city by wearing any uniform or portion thereof that is issued by the city while he/she is participating in any campaign at any time. 
(e)  The city in no way seeks to influence employees in their choice of party affiliations or candidates, recognizing that this is a matter for each person to decide. Therefore, nothing contained herein shall be construed to restrict the right of the employee to hold membership in and support a political party, to vote as he/she chooses, to express opinions on political subjects or candidates, to maintain political neutrality, to attend political parties after work hours, or to campaign actively during off duty hours in all areas of political activity. 
(f)  Employees shall not utilize any city equipment or vehicles in support of any political campaign. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-7), 4-2-2002) 
Sec. 2-6-8. - Board of ethics. 
(a)  Members. The board of ethics shall consist of five members. The mayor and council shall appoint each of the five members. The city attorney shall act as legal counsel to the board, and shall cast no vote on any subject which comes before the board. At any meeting of the board three members shall constitute a quorum. The board shall elect one of the members as chairman. The chairman may vote on any matter that comes before the board where no conflict exists. The members shall be designated member one, member two, member three, member four and member five, only for purposes of staggering their terms of service. Each member of the board of ethics shall be a resident of the city at the time of appointment and for at least one year immediately preceding the date of taking office and shall remain a resident of the city while serving as a member of the board of ethics. No person shall serve as a member of the board of ethics if the person has or has had within the preceding one-year period, any interest in any contract, transaction, or official action of the city. The members of the board of ethics shall serve staggered three-year terms after the terms of the original members are completed. Starting on January 1, 2005, member one's term shall end. The term of member two shall end on January 1, 2006. The term of member three shall end on January 1, 2007. The term of member four shall end on January 1, 2008. The term of member five shall end on January 1, 2009. The three-year terms of future board members shall thereafter continue as staggered. The members of the board of ethics shall serve without compensation. However, travel and other expenses incurred on behalf of the city may be repaid. The mayor and council of the city shall provide meeting space for the board of ethics. Subject to budgetary procedures and requirements of the city, the city shall provide the board of ethics with such supplies and equipment as may be reasonably necessary for it to perform its duties and responsibilities. 
(b)  Criminal background check. Prior to appointment by the mayor and council, candidates for the board of ethics must agree to undergo a criminal background check conducted by the police department prior to designation, the results of which will be forwarded to the mayor and council. Upon appointment each individual shall attend a training session on the Ethics Ordinance conducted by the city. 
(c)  Duties and powers. The constituted board of ethics shall have the following duties and powers: 
(1)  To establish procedures, rules and regulations governing its internal organization and conduct of its affairs; 
(2)  To meet within 60 days after the receipt of a complaint, to decide if the same is in the proper form and if so to decide whether or not the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to involve the disciplinary jurisdiction of the mayor and council or if further action in a full hearing is necessary; 
(3)  To prescribe forms, approved by the city attorney, for the disclosures required in this article, and to make available to the public information disclosed as provided in this section; 
(4)  To receive and hear complaints of violations of the standards required by this article; 
(5)  To make such investigation and response to a complaint as it deems necessary to determine whether any person has violated any provisions of this article; 
(6)  To hold such hearings and made such inquiries as deemed necessary to be investigated and rule upon complaints; 
(7)  To report its findings to the mayor and council for such action as the mayor and council deems appropriate; 
(8)  To vote on all issues which come before the board. The chairman may vote on all issues and not simply to break a tie; and 
(9)  To meet to hear issues. A quorum shall be constituted by the presence of all three members of the board, no proxies shall be allowed. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-8), 4-2-2002; Ord. No. 2004-13, §§ 1, 2, 8-3-2004; Ord. No. 2009-13, § 1, 8-18-2009) 
Sec. 2-6-9. - Receipt of complaints. 
(a)  The board may meet and decide a complaint is not in proper form. If such decision is made, the complainant will be so notified and advised as to the deficiencies found in the complaint. A decision of sufficiency as to form must be made within 30 days of the receipt of the complaint. 
(b)  All complaints against city officials shall be filed with the board of ethics whether received by the mayor, city attorney, or the board itself. The board of ethics shall require that oral complaints, and complaints illegibly or informally drawn, be reduced to a sworn memorandum of complaint in such form as may be prescribed by the city attorney. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the board of ethics shall review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the mayor and council. The board of ethics shall be empowered to collect evidence and information concerning any complaint and to add the findings and results of its investigations to the file containing such complaint. 
(d)  Upon completion of its investigation of a complaint, the board of ethics shall be empowered to dismiss those complaints which are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of mayor and council; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the board of ethics shall not deprive the complaining party of any action he/she might otherwise have at law or in equity against the respondent government servant. A rejection shall prevent refiling of a complaint regarding the same subject(s) and alleged perpetrator(s) for the same offense within six months of the original complaint filing. 
(e)  The board of ethics shall be empowered to conduct probable cause investigations, to take evidence and hold hearings where provided for in this article. 
(f)  The board of ethics shall be empowered to adopt forms for formal complaints, notices, applications, and any other written instruments necessary or desirable under these rules. The board of ethics may order any city official to attend any hearing as set forth hereinbelow. 
(g)  If a complaint is already the subject of pending litigation, the board may elect to table the matter until such time as the litigation is concluded. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-9), 4-2-2002; Ord. No. 2004-13, § 3, 8-3-2004) 
Sec. 2-6-10. - Service of complaint; hearing and disposition of complaints. 
(a)  The board of ethics, in any case, shall cause the complaint to be served on the public official charged as soon as practicable. Service may be personal service or certified mail, return receipt requested. Within 60 days of the receipt of a complaint, a hearing shall be held to take appropriate action under section 2-6-9, as to dismissal, or under this section, as to a full hearing, as needed. A party may provide a court reporter for an exact transcript. However, the city shall not be compelled to provide a written transcription. The decision of the board of ethics shall be rendered and submitted to the mayor and council within five days after completion of the hearing. 
(b)  The board of ethics shall conduct the hearing in accordance with the procedures and regulations it establishes, but in all circumstances, the hearing shall include the following: 
(1)  Generally, the hearing shall be conducted following the same procedures of court hearings in the state. 
(2)  The chairman of the board of ethics shall conduct the hearing. 
(3)  The person who filed the complaint shall present his case to the board first. 
(4)  Each witness presented by the complaint, and including the complainant, shall be subject to cross-examination by the individual accused of the ethical violation or such person's representative. 
(5)  At the conclusion of the complainant's case, the respondent shall be entitled to move for dismissal based on insufficient evidence on the part of the complaint. If respondent makes such a motion and the board, by the majority vote, agrees to dismiss the complaint, the hearing shall be terminated. If either the respondent fails to make such a motion, or, if the board decides by majority vote to overrule respondent's motion, the hearing shall continue. 
(6)  Respondent shall then be entitled to present his evidence to the board, if he so chooses. 
(7)  Respondent shall then be entitled to testify. The absence of respondent's testimony shall not be viewed by the board as an admission of any sort. 
(8)  If respondent testifies, then respondent shall be subject to cross-examination by complainant. All other witnesses who testify in the respondent's case shall be subject to cross-examination by complainant. 
(9)  All persons who testify before the board shall be placed under oath, by either the chairman or a person designated by the chairman or the city attorney. The oath shall read as follows: 
"Do you solemnly swear or affirm that the testimony you are about to give in this matter shall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?" 
(10)  At the conclusion of respondent's case, the complainant may offer rebuttal evidence only to those items presented in respondent's case. At the conclusion of complainant's rebuttal, respondent shall be entitled to offer rebuttal evidence only to those matters presented in complainant's rebuttal case. 
(11)  At the conclusion of all of the testimony and closure of all of the evidence, the board members may ask questions of any of the individuals who testified before the board. 
(12)  At the conclusion of all questions by board members, the chairman shall end the hearing and permit the board to deliberate in public. If the board decides by majority vote that additional evidence is needed to make a decision, the board shall have the authority to conduct its own investigation or to require either the complainant or respondent, subject to the respondents right against self incrimination unless the same is waived by respondent, to submit additional evidence at a continuation of the hearing which must be held no later than 45 days after the date of the initial hearing. The board has no authority to continue the hearing past the 45-day deadline. The board cannot require the respondent to testify if he has not already done so, and the respondent cannot be forced to incriminate himself unless he has already testified, presented evidence, or in some matter waived his right against self-incrimination. 
(13)  Receipt of additional evidence shall follow the same format outlined hereinabove. Following the conclusion of any additional evidence received at the continued hearing, the board shall continue deliberation then the chairman shall call for a vote. The board's first vote must be whether or not the respondent violated the ethics code as charged by the complainant. If, by majority vote, the board rules that the respondent did not violate the ethics code as charged by the complainant, then the matter is concluded. If the board, by majority vote, concludes that the respondent did violate the ethics code as charged by complainant, then the board must make a second decision by majority vote as to the appropriate penalty. 
(14)  At any hearing held by the board of ethics, the public official who is the subject of inquiry shall have the right to written notice of the complaint at least ten business days before a hearing, to be represented by counsel, to hear and examine the evidence and witnesses, and to present evidence and witnesses in opposition or in extenuation and to be provided copies of any document in possession of the city or complainant to be used against them at least five business days in advance of the hearing. Failure to provide such documents shall preclude their submission and consideration by the board. 
(15)  The complainant's evidence must prove that respondent is guilty of the offense charged by the evidentiary standard commonly referred as "preponderance of the evidence." 
(16)  If any question concerning the hearing procedures which is not otherwise addressed in this article arise, the city attorney, or in his absence, the appointed legal advisor to the board shall resolve the procedural question by advisory opinion then said opinion shall be adopted or declined by the board. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-10), 4-2-2002; Ord. No. 2004-13, §§ 4, 5, 8-3-2004) 
Sec. 2-6-11. - Penalties. 
    Any public official who knowingly violates any provision of the code of ethics provided in this article shall be subject to public reprimand or censure. If, in the opinion of the board of ethics, the matter warrants such action, the matter may be sent to the solicitor pro hac vice for review for trial in city court, or to another law enforcement agency for investigation. A decision of the board recommending public reprimand, censure or referral to a law enforcement agency may be appealed to the superior court. Superior court review shall be limited to an inquiry of whether or not there was any evidence before the administrative board, which supported their decision. If a conviction results in city court, said offense shall be punishable as a misdemeanor, and may result in a $1,000.00 fine and/or 60 days in jail. 
(Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1(2-7-11), 4-2-2002) 
ARTICLE 7. - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal courts, O.C.G.A. § 36-32-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-7-1. - Judge; qualifications, compensation. 
    The municipal court judge shall be an active member in good standing of the State Bar of Georgia, and shall receive such compensation as fixed by the mayor and council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-1; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-2. - Court sessions; when held, generally; opening announcement. 
    A regular session of the municipal court shall be held at a fixed hour of a fixed day as may be determined by the judge, provided any session may be dispensed with when there is no business pending in the court or no cases are ready for trial. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-2; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-3. - Special sessions. 
    The municipal court may hold special sessions when, in the judge's opinion, it is necessary or there is urgent cause for the trial of accused persons before the next regular sitting of the court. The necessity or urgency of the cause shall be presumed from the fact of a session being held. All defendants shall have at least 24 hours' notice of the session. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-3; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-4. - Police attendance. 
    It shall be the duty of some member of the police force designated by the chief of police, with the consent of the city administrator, to attend each session of the court to act as bailiff. It shall be the duty of each police officer making the arrest or having knowledge of the case for or against the defendant to attend the trial of any person brought before the court. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-4; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-5. - Clerk of court, subpoenas; dockets. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city administrator, with the consent of the municipal court judge, to provide a clerk to attend each session of the court and serve as clerk of court. 
(b)  The clerk of court shall: 
(1)  Prepare all subpoenas and warrants and maintain a docket thereof that will show the name of the person for whom the subpoena or warrant was issued, its date, at whose instance it was issued and to whom delivered. 
(2)  At the request of the municipal court judge, maintain a duplicate court docket and to use the signed duplicate copy of the docket to make necessary entries in the master docket after each session of court. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-5; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-6. - Jury trial; bind over. 
(a)  All charges cognizable as violations of state laws shall be handled by a commitment hearing; provided, however, that they may be adjudicated in the municipal court whenever the court would have jurisdiction over the offense, and the defendant, in writing, waives any right to trial by jury. 
(b)  When a defendant is bound over to the appropriate state court, he or she may be released under any of the following methods: 
(1)  If the defendant has posted bond to the city, he or she may be released on the same bond. 
(2)  If the defendant has not posted bond before being bound over, the defendant shall be delivered, in person, by the city police to the county authorities. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-6; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-7. - Appearance bond; acceptance procedure. 
    Offenses against the ordinances of the city shall be bailable as follows: 
(1)  The clerk of court, municipal court judge, shift commander or any other officer designated by the city administrator may accept bond of the accused payable to the city conditioned upon the appearance of the accused at the next session, or any subsequent session of the court as stated in the bond, to answer the charge. In the event that the shift commander accepts a cash bond from the accused, such acceptance must be witnessed by another officer. 
(2)  The bond shall be in writing in an amount established in a schedule approved by the mayor and council. Cash bonds shall be allowed in the same amount. 
(3)  A person arrested for violation of a city ordinance may be released on his or her own recognizance if the municipal court judge determines that the person will appear at the time set for the court appearance in view of the following considerations: 
a.  The seriousness of the offense charged; 
b.  The penalty provided by law; 
c.  The number of charges pending against the defendant; 
d.  The criminal record of the defendant; 
e.  The residence of the defendant and the length of time of residence; 
f.  The defendant's age; 
g.  The defendant's marital status and number of children; 
h.  Residency of the relatives of the defendant; 
i.  Employment of defendant (by whom, nature of work and how long employed); 
j.  Former employment; 
k.  Amount of earnings; 
l.  The defendant's character, reputation and previous criminal history; 
m.  The defendant's mental condition; and 
n.  Whether the defendant has membership in any clubs or societies, church affiliation and other things which could show that he or she is a responsible member of the community with established community ties. 
(4)  Any person released under subsection (3) above shall receive a receipt for any driver's license deposited or, if released on the person's own recognizance, shall sign and receive a copy of the citation or ticket describing the violation for which the person was arrested. 
(5)  All persons arrested or notified by citation or ticket of parking violations shall be released on their own recognizance. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-7; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-8. - Continuance of cases. 
    Continuances shall be made only for good cause shown. The municipal court judge or clerk of court under the judge's supervision may grant continuations of a case. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-8; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-9. - Forfeiture of appearance bonds. 
(a)  The presiding judge shall call the case in its regular order, and, if the accused is not in court and does not answer the call, and, if no good and sufficient reason is given for nonappearance, the judge shall enter on the docket where the case is stated "bond forfeited," or similar words. 
(b)  Upon forfeiture of any bond, the cash deposited as security shall become the property of the city. 
(c)  Upon the forfeiture of any bond signed by a person as surety, the clerk shall issue an execution against the principal and surety on the bond for the amount thereof which shall be collected as tax executions are collected. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-9; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-10. - Acceptance of pleas. 
    Before accepting a plea to an offense charged, the court shall in all cases, in language which the defendant can understand, inform the defendant of the nature of the charge and the penalty which may be imposed upon conviction, and shall inform the defendant of his or her fundamental constitutional rights. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-10; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-11. - Pleas. 
(a)  The defendant shall enter one of the following pleas: 
(1)  Guilty; 
(2)  Non guilty; 
(3)  Nolo contendere (with the permission of the court); or 
(4)  A former judgment of conviction or acquittal of the offense charged. 
(b)  If the defendant refuses to enter a plea, the court shall enter a plea of not guilty and set the case down for trial. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-11; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-12. - Fines; enforcement by levy and execution; payment in advance of court date. 
(a)  For fines that may be due by any defendant, execution may be issued by the city clerk and collected as tax executions are collected. 
(b)  Persons charged with traffic violations may, prior to the time for their court appearance, plead guilty in writing and pay to the city, as their fine, the amount set as the appearance bond for the offense charged; except that those persons charged with driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs and those charged with an offense in connection with an automobile collision shall be required in all cases to appear before the court for disposition of the case. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-12; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-13. - Appearance of complaining witnesses; subpoena of witnesses. 
(a)  A material or complaining witness in any contested prosecution shall appear at the session at which the prosecution is docketed. The prosecution may be dismissed if the material witness fails to appear. 
(b)  The attendance of witnesses may be enforced by subpoena. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-13; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-14. - Rules of evidence. 
    The general rules of evidence shall be applicable in the trial of all cases. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-14; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-15. - Judgment and sentences. 
    Upon a judgment of plea of guilty the court shall impose sentence. The court may: 
(1)  Impose a fine, with or without a commitment for confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(2)  Commit the defendant to confinement, compulsory work or both; 
(3)  Suspend the execution of the sentence in whole or in part; or 
(4)  Defer the execution of the sentence or any portion or portions thereof to one or more fixed dates in the future. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-15; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-16. - Court dates; contempt warrants. 
(a)  Court date shall be made known to the defendant at the time of the arrest process and shall be properly indicated on the copy of the charges given to the defendant by the arresting officer. 
(b)  Arrest warrants for contempt of court charges may be issued following each session of court. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-16; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-17. - Appearance of persons charged; failure to appear, penalty. 
(a)  In any case where any person is charged with the violation of any of the provisions of this code or any other ordinances of the city and a copy of charges or other citations is delivered to the person requiring an appearance before the municipal court of the city at a specified time and place, it shall be the duty of that person to appear at the time and place set out in the charges or citations. 
(b)  Any person failing to appear at the time and place set out in the charges or citations shall be guilty of contempt of court. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-17; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
Sec. 2-7-18. - Court costs. 
    The costs in all cases tried before the municipal court shall be established by resolution of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1981, § 2-6-18; Ord. No. 96-02, § 1, 7-9-1996) 
ARTICLE 8. - ANNEXATION OF UNINCORPORATED ISLAND 2006 

Sec. 2-8-1. - Annexation of unincorporated island. 
    Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 36-36-90 et seq., an unincorporated Fulton County island contiguous and abutting the City of Hapeville, Georgia, along the greatest percentage of external boundary is hereby annexed into the City Limits of the City of Hapeville, Georgia as of March 7, 2006. 
(Ord. No. 2006-02, § 1, 3-7-2006) 
Sec. 2-8-2. - Identification of formerly unincorporated island. 
    The land area to be annexed is hereby identified on a map physically attached to the original adopting ordinance [Ordinance No. 2006-02] and included therein as exhibit "A." Said ordinance is located in the Official Minutes of the City of Hapeville, Georgia, and is maintained at and may be accessed for public inspection by all affected in the office of the city clerk. The map is deemed a public record. 
(Ord. No. 2006-02, § 1, 3-7-2006) 
Chapter 5 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1]

ARTICLE 1. - LICENSING GENERALLY 

Sec. 5-1-1. - Purposes. 
    The purposes of this chapter shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Compliance with and effectuation of state law; 
(2)  Promotion and effectuation of the city's land use and zoning policies/plans; 
(3)  Prevention of the unlawful sale and use of alcohol;
