If more than one outlet is required at any of the said locations, a grantee shall install at the cost of time and material only, and in no event will there be a monthly service charge at said locations except for additional outlets. 
(8)  That a grantee shall make its studio facilities, including color cameras and other equipment, available for use by public and private schools for local organization programs and for closed circuit educational films subject to reasonable rules and regulations pertaining to such use by grantee and in such manner as to not unduly interfere with the cable television operations of a grantee. Services rendered to all users by a grantee under the terms of the franchise shall at all times be as good as the state of the art allows. 
(9)  That a grantee shall provide at least one free dedicated noncommercial public access channel to be available. 
(10)  That a grantee shall reserve at least one channel solely for educational use on a developmental basis, and that upon completion of the basic trunk line, for the first five years thereafter at least one channel will be made available free. 
(11)  That a grantee shall reserve at least one channel solely for use by state and local governments on a developmental basis and that, upon completion of the basic trunk line, for the first five years thereafter at least one channel will remain free. 
(12)  That the CATV system shall be installed with the capacity for two-way communication in accordance with the regulations of the FCC now in effect or which may be promulgated. 
(c)  A grantee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly and interrupt service only for such good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruptions, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system. 
(d)  A grantee shall maintain an office in the county which shall be open during all usual business hours, have necessary listed telephones, and be so operated that complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments may be received at any time. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-14; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-15. - Supervision by city. 
(a)  A grantee shall construct, operate and maintain the CATV system subject to the supervision of all of the authorities of the city who have jurisdiction in such matters and in strict compliance with all laws, ordinances and departmental rules and regulations. 
(b)  The CATV system and all parts thereof shall be subject to the right of periodic inspection by the city. 
(c)  The city engineer may, from time to time, issue such reasonable rules and regulations concerning the construction, operation and maintenance of the CATV system as are consistent with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  If at any time the powers of the governing body or any agency or official of the city are transferred by law to any other board, authority, agency or official, the transferee shall have the powers, rights and duties previously vested under this article or by law in the governing body or any agency or official of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-15; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-16. - Grantee's duty to remove its properties from the public streets. 
(a)  Following a grantee's commencement of service through and over its CATV system, a grantee shall promptly remove from the public streets where its properties are located all or any part of the facilities so located when one or more of the following enumerated conditions occur: 
(1)  A grantee ceases to operate the CATV system for a continuous period of six months from the date of said occurrence. 
(2)  A grantee fails to construct said system as hereinabove and hereafter provided. 
(3)  The franchise is terminated or revoked pursuant to notice as provided herein. 
(b)  A grantee shall be entitled to receive notice in writing from the city setting forth one or more of the occurrences hereinabove enumerated or such other occurrences hereinbefore or hereinafter provided and shall have 90 days from the date upon which said notice is received to remove such properties as hereinabove required. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-16; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-17. - Operational reports. 
(a)  Within six months from the acceptance date of the franchise, a grantee shall submit to the city engineer and the administrative officer an installation plan for the entire city, indicating the date on which a grantee expects the installation of the CATV system to be completed and available for service to subscribers in the various areas of the city. 
(b)  A grantee shall furnish the city engineer with progress reports indicating in detail the area of construction of the CATV system. Such periodic reports shall be furnished at three-month intervals, the first report to be made three months after the construction commencement date. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-17; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-18. - Off-the-air programming. 
(a)  A grantee shall carry the signals of all television stations licensed to communities within 35 miles of the city pursuant to the rules and regulations of the FCC. 
(b)  A grantee may also transmit or distribute the full output on FM radio stations provided that a grantee transmits or distributes all of the FM stations the broadcasting studios of which are now located within the city or within 35 miles of the limits thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-18; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-19. - Cablecasting on city and public channels. 
    For the presentation of programming on public channels, a grantee shall make available free time and, if necessary, adequate studio facilities to members of the public at rates filed with the governing body and subject to the governing body's review in accordance with the provisions of section 2-3-9. Appropriate technical assistance shall also be furnished by a grantee. Time shall be provided on a first-come, first-served basis, except that a grantee shall endeavor to grant such channel time to as many different persons as is practical, it being the intention of the governing body that such public channels serve as a significant source of diversified expression. In order that there is a maximum opportunity for freedom of expression by members of the public, such programming shall be free from any control by a grantee as to program content, except as is required to protect a grantee from liability under applicable law. The governing body may direct that a grantee discontinue, or not deliver, a program on the public channels which it finds to be essentially promotional or otherwise related primarily to the conduct of a business, trade or profession; provided, however, this provision shall not be construed as a prohibition of advertiser-supported programming on public channels. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-19; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-20. - Local event blackout. 
    If any local event within the metropolitan area is blacked out or not telecast within said area pursuant to and within the terms of any agreement by or with the owners, authorized distributors or licensees of such event, such event shall not be transmitted or delivered by a grantee notwithstanding the source of such event or its TV picture signals except under the rules and regulations adopted by the FCC The word "event" means any live entertainment or sports contest. A grantee shall be required to show proof of written permission if requested. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-20; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-21. - Emergency use of the facilities. 
(a)  In the event of any emergency or disaster, a grantee shall, upon request of the administrative office, make available its facilities to the city at no cost for emergency use during the period of such emergency or disaster and shall provide such personnel as necessary to properly operate under the circumstances. 
(b)  A grantee shall incorporate into its facilities the capability for an emergency override alert whereby the city, in times of crisis, may be able to introduce a bulletin on all channels simultaneously. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-21; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-22. - Compliance with state and federal laws. 
(a)  A grantee shall, at all times, comply with all laws and regulations of the state and federal governments or any administrative agency thereof, and if any state or federal law or regulation shall require a grantee to perform any service or shall prohibit a grantee from performing any service or shall permit a grantee to perform any service in conflict with the terms of the franchise or of any laws or regulation of the city, then as soon as possible following knowledge thereof, a grantee shall notify the administrative officer of the point of conflict believed to exist between such regulation of law and the laws or regulations of the city or franchise, and a grantee shall be governed by the advice of the administrative officer. 
(b)  A grantee shall be subject to all city ordinances as set forth herein, and a grantee shall also be subject to all applicable rules and regulations which, from time to time, may be promulgated by the FCC for CATV systems. 
(c)  If the governing body determines that material provision of this article is affected by such subsequent action, the governing body shall have the right to modify any of the provisions herein to such reasonable extent as may be necessary to carry out the full intent and purpose of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-22; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-23. - Filing communications with regulatory agencies. 
    Copies of all petitions, applications and communications submitted by a grantee to the FCC, SEC or any other federal or state regulatory commission or agency having jurisdiction in respect to any matter affecting CATV operation shall also be submitted simultaneously to the city. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-23; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-24. - Restrictions on transfer, assignment, etc., of franchise. 
(a)  The franchise shall not be assigned or transferred, either in whole or in part, leased or sublet in any manner, nor shall title thereto, either legal or equitable, or any right, interest or property therein, pass to or vest in any person either by the act of a grantee or by operation of law without the consent of the governing body. The granting, giving or waiving of any one or more of such consents shall not render unnecessary any subsequent consent or consents. 
(b)  The consent or approval of the governing body to any assignment, lease, transfer or sublease of the franchise shall not constitute a waiver or release of the rights of the city in and to the streets. 
(c)  Prior approval of the governing body shall be required where ownership or control of more than ten percent of the right of control of a grantee is acquired by a person or group of persons acting in concert, none of whom already owns or controls ten percent or more of such right of control, singularly or collectively, at the date the franchise is granted. By its acceptance of the franchise, a grantee specifically agrees that any such acquisition occurring without prior approval of the governing body shall constitute a violation of this article by a grantee. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to prohibit a mortgage or pledge of the CATV system equipment or any part thereof or a leasing by a grantee from another person to said CATV system equipment or part thereof for financing purposes or otherwise. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-24; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-25. - Preferential or discriminatory practices. 
    A grantee shall not, as to rates, charges, service facilities, rules, regulations or in any other respect, make or grant any undue preference or advantage to any person or subject any person to any undue prejudice or disadvantage; provided, however, connection and service charges may be waived or modified during promotional campaigns of grantee. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-25; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-26. - Revocation of franchise. 
(a)  In addition to all the rights and powers reserved or pertaining to the city, the city reserves as an additional and as a separate and distinct power the right to terminate the franchise and all rights and privileges of a grantee hereunder in any of the following events or for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  A grantee shall by act or omission violate any term or condition of this article and within 30 days following written demand by the city shall fail to effect compliance. 
(2)  Any provision of this article shall be finally adjudged by a court of law invalid or unenforceable and the governing body further finds that such provision constitutes at that time a consideration material to the continuance of the franchise herein granted. 
(3)  A grantee becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts or is adjudged a bankrupt or all or part of a grantee's facilities are or are to be sold under an instrument to secure a debt and are not redeemable by grantee within 30 days from said sale. 
(4)  A grantee attempts to or does practice any fraud or deceit in its conduct or relations under the franchise with the city or subscribers or potential subscribers. 
(b)  A grantee shall not be declared at fault or be subject to any sanction under any provision of this article in any case in which performance of any such provision is prevented for reasons beyond its control. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-26; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-27. - Procedures. 
(a)  Any injury, proceeding, investigation or other action to be taken or proposed to be taken by the administrative officer and the governing body in regard to the operations of a grantee's cable television system other than as provided in subsection (c) of this section, but including action in regard to a change in subscription rates, shall be taken only after 30 days' public notice of such action or proposed action is published in a local daily or weekly newspaper having general circulation in the city; a copy of such action or proposed action is served directly on grantee; and the grantee has been given an opportunity to respond in writing and/or at hearing as may be specified by the administrative officer and governing body, and general members of the public have been given an opportunity to respond or comment in writing on the action or proposed action. 
(b)  The public notice required by this section shall state clearly the action or proposed action to be taken, the time provided for response and the persons in authority to whom such response should be addressed, and such other procedures as may be specified by the administrative officer and governing body. If a hearing is to be held, the public notice shall give the date and time of such hearing, whether public participation will be allowed and the procedures by which such participation may be obtained. The grantee is a necessary party to any hearing conducted in regard to its operations. 
(c)  An informal complaint shall be submitted to the administrative officer and governing body in writing and shall contain the name and address of the complainant, the name of the cable system against which the complaint is made and a complete statement of facts upon which the complaint is based. 
(1)  Upon receipt of any informal complaint, the administrative officer and governing body will forward a copy to the system complained of or may take the question up by correspondence with the system. Within such time as may be prescribed by the administrative officer and the governing body, the system will be called upon to satisfy the complaint or advise the administrative officer and governing body of its refusal or inability to do so. If the system satisfies the complaint, it shall so notify the administrative officer and the governing body in accordance with the provisions of subsection (c)(2) hereof. The administrative officer and governing body will forward a copy of the system's notice of satisfaction to the complainant. If the system refuses or is unable to satisfy the complaint, it shall so notify the administrative officer and governing body, and the administrative officer and governing body will forward a copy of such notice to the complainant, with a statement of the procedure to be followed to further prosecute the complaint. 
(2)  If a system satisfies any complaint brought to its attention by the administrative officer and governing body, a statement must be filed with the administrative officer and governing body setting forth when and how the complainant has been satisfied. 
(3)  When a complaint has not been satisfied pursuant to subsection (c)(2) above, the complainant may file a formal complaint with the administrative officer and governing body in the form and manner to be specified thereby. The complaint to the administrative officer and governing body must be filed within six months from the date of the administrative officer's and governing body's statement accompanying a copy of the system's notice of refusal or inability to satisfy the complaint, and the complaint to the administrative officer and governing body must take reference to the date of the complaint filed with the administrative officer and governing body and that it is based on the same facts as the complaint filed with the administrative officer and governing body. If no complaint is filed with the administrative officer and governing body within six months period, the complainant will be deemed to have abandoned his complaint, and such complaint will be deemed dismissed. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-27; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-28. - Grantee to have no recourse. 
(a)  Except as expressly provided in the franchise, a grantee herein shall have no recourse whatsoever against the city for any loss, cost or expenses or damage arising out of the provisions or requirements of the franchise or because of the enforcement thereof by the city, nor for the failure of the city to have the authority to grant all or any part of the franchise. 
(b)  A grantee expressly acknowledges that upon accepting a franchise, it does so relying upon its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the city to grant the franchise. 
(c)  A grantee by acceptance of the franchise acknowledges that it has not been induced to enter into the franchise by any understanding or promise or other statement whether verbal or written by or on behalf of the city or by any other third person concerning any term or condition of the franchise not expressed herein. 
(d)  A grantee further acknowledges by acceptance of the franchise that it has carefully read the terms and conditions hereof and is willing to and does accept all of the risks of the meaning of such terms and conditions and agrees that in the event of any ambiguity therein or in the event of any other dispute over the meaning thereof, the same shall be construed strictly against a grantee and in favor of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-28; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-29. - Failure of city to enforce the franchise; no waiver of the terms thereof. 
    A grantee shall not be excused from complying with any of the terms and conditions of the franchise by any failure of the city upon any one or more occasions to insist upon or to seek compliance with any such terms or conditions. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-29; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-30. - Time essence of agreement. 
    Whenever the franchise shall set forth any time for any act to be performed by or on behalf of a grantee, such time shall be deemed of the essence, and any failure of a grantee to perform within the time allotted shall always be sufficient grounds for the city to revoke the franchise. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-30; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-31. - Grantee will not contest validity of franchise. 
    A grantee agrees by the acceptance of the franchise that it will not at any time set up against the city in any claim or proceeding any condition or term of the franchise as unreasonable, arbitrary or void or that the city had no power or authority to make such term or condition, but shall be required to accept the validity of the terms and conditions of the franchise in their entirety. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-31; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-32. - Rights reserved to the city. 
    Without limitation upon the rights which the city might otherwise have, the city does hereby expressly reserve the following rights, powers and authorities: 
(1)  To exercise its governmental powers now or hereafter to the full extent that such powers may be vested in or granted to said city. 
(2)  To determine through the governing body any question of fact relating to the meaning, terms, obligations or other factors of the franchise. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-32; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-33. - Acceptance. 
    This article and its terms and provisions shall be accepted by a grantee by a written franchise agreement executed and acknowledged by a grantee and filed with the city clerk. Said agreement shall incorporate grantee's written application to the city for the CATV franchise and shall bind grantee to the provisions of said application. The governing body may require a grantee to clarify any portion of its written application prior to final acceptance. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-33; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-34. - Extension of city limits. 
    Upon the annexation of any territory to the city (other than through a governmental consolidation process, as to which the city makes no agreement), the right and franchise hereby granted shall extend to the territory so annexed to the extent the city has authority; and all facilities owned, maintained or operated by a grantee, located within, under or over streets of the territory so annexed, shall thereafter be subject to all terms hereof. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-34; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-35. - Local office. 
    During the term of the franchise, and any renewal thereof, the grantee shall maintain in the city a local business office or agent. The provisions of this section shall be complied with if the grantee maintains a local business headquarters office within ten air miles of the center of the city; provides the administrative officer and governing body with the name, address and phone number of a resident of the county who will act as the grantee's agent to receive complaints regarding quality of service, equipment malfunctions and similar matters; and at least once a week informs all subscribers by appropriate announcement (e.g., by a slide card) over the system's originations cablecasting channel of the name, address and phone number of the grantee's registered agent for the city. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-35; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-36. - Pay television. 
    A grantee shall not engage in pay television except under conditions affirmatively authorized by the FCC. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-36; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
Sec. 38-3-37. - Modification of FCC rules. 
    Consistent with the requirements of rule 76.31(a)(6) of the FCC, any modification of rule 76.31 resulting from amendment thereto by the FCC shall, to the extent applicable, be considered as a part of the franchise as of the effective date of the amendment made by the FCC and shall be incorporated in such franchise by specific amendments thereto by the lawful action of the governing body within one year from the effective date of the FCC's amendment or at the time of renewal of the franchise, whichever occurs first. 
(Code 1981, § 9-5-37; Ord. No. 79-7, 7-3-1979; Ord. No. 86-12, 11-18-1986) 
ARTICLE 4. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS FRANCHISES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, adopted May 7, 2002, enacted provisions intended for use as title 9, chapter 7, sections 9-7-1-9-7-20. Inasmuch as this ordinance was inadvertently omitted during the recodification, and at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been redesignated as chapter 38, article 4, sections 38-4-1-38-4-20. 

Sec. 38-4-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish guidelines for the granting, issuance and regulation of franchises to companies desiring to construct, operate or maintain telecommunications systems over which telecommunications services are provided, or to companies desiring to provide facility services within the territorial boundaries of the city on the terms and conditions described in each franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-2. - Definitions. 
    Affiliated person means each person who falls into one or more of the following categories: (1) each person having, directly or indirectly, a controlling interest in the applicant; (2) each person in which the applicant has, directly or indirectly, a controlling interest; (3) each officer, director, joint venturer or joint venture partner, or the applicant; and, (4) each person, directly or indirectly, controlling, controlled by, or under common control with, the applicant; provided that "affiliated person" shall in no event mean the city or any creditor of the applicant solely by virtue of its status as a creditor and which is not otherwise an affiliated person by reason of owning a controlling interest in, being owned by, or being under common ownership, common management or common control with, the applicant. 
    City means the City of Hapeville. 
    City council means the city council of the city and its designee or any successor thereto. 
    Facility services means the installation, construction, operation or maintenance of conduit or related facilities in the streets by a person for sale or lease to third parties, other than affiliated persons, that use such conduit or related facilities for the transmission of telecommunication services, but such person does not itself provide telecommunications service or cable service to such third parties or any locations or other persons in the license area. 
    Franchise means an initial authorization, or renewal thereof, issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article, which authorizes the occupation and use of the streets by a telecommunications system to provide telecommunications services. 
    Grantee means the legal entity to which is granted the right, authority and responsibility to provide facility services along licensed routes pursuant to a license, or to construct, install, operate and maintain a telecommunications system as necessary to: (1) furnish, supply and distribute telecommunications services to any locations or persons in the franchise or license area; (2) provide private telecommunications services along licensed routes pursuant to a license; or (3) transport telecommunications services across the city along licensed routes pursuant to a license without terminating or originating any telecommunications services at or from any person or location in the city. 
    May is permissive. 
    Ordinance means this article and all modifications and amendments thereto. 
    Person means any individual or any association, firm, partnership, joint venture, corporation or other legally recognized entity, whether for profit or not for profit, but shall not mean the city. 
    Private telecommunications services means the transmission of telecommunications by a person, regardless of the facilities used, for or in connection with the internal operations of such person's business, residence or employment and not for or in connection with the provision or offering of telecommunications services for sale or resale to any person, and shall not mean cable services. 
    Revocable license means an initial authorization or renewal thereof, issued by the city in accordance with the provisions of this article, which authorizes the occupation and use of specifically identified streets, provided that a revocable license shall be issued only in the limited circumstances set forth in this article. 
    Shall is mandatory, not merely directive. 
    Streets means the surface of, as well as the spaces above and below, any and all streets, alleyways, avenues, highways, boulevards, driveways, bridges, tunnels, parks, parkways, public grounds or waters, and other public rights-of-way within or belonging to the city. 
    Telecommunications means "telecommunications" as defined by 47 U.S.C. § 153(43) of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, but shall not include cable services. 
    Telecommunications service means "telecommunications service" as defined by 47 U.S.C. § 153(46) of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, but shall not include cable services. In the event that "telecommunications service" is no longer defined in the Communications Act or the definition in the Communications Act otherwise becomes inapplicable, "telecommunications service" shall mean "telecommunications Service" as defined in the Communications Act immediately prior to such term no longer being defined in the Communications Act or such definition otherwise becoming inapplicable. 
    Telecommunications system means the system, plant, equipment or property within the streets in the franchise or license area over which telecommunications service or private telecommunications service is provided, and to be constructed, operated and maintained by a grantee pursuant to a franchise or license ordinance or agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-3. - Franchise required. 
    Prior to any person, firm, corporation, or other entity using the city right-of-way by constructing, installing, altering, or repairing lines, devices, or other physical objects within the city right-of-way as part of any commercial enterprise then a franchise must be gained by the mayor and council of the city. For the purposes of this article only, the term "using the city right-of-way" shall be defined as any activity that affects: the preservation of the physical and aesthetic integrity of city streets and highways, the orderly flow of vehicles and pedestrians, the management and safety of gas, water, cable, electric and telecommunication oriented (except for television) and telephone facilities that are located in or occupying any street, road, alley, sidewalk or other public place in said city, for public utility purposes, such as electric light plant, electric or steam or other streetcar line or road, gas line, railroad line, telephone line, telegraph line, telecommunication facilities, express line, waterworks, or other public utility service, whether the same be surface, underground, overhead or otherwise, except as hereinafter provided, in city right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-4. - Procedure for grant of franchise. 
(a)  Application in writing, signed by the applicant, shall be made to and filed with the department of community services for such franchise, license or right, setting forth what streets or areas are to be occupied and for what purpose. The department of community services shall be responsible for ensuring the completeness of the application. Upon receipt of a complete application, the department of community services shall inform the mayor and council of its receipt. Two weeks notice of application shall be given by the clerk of council by posting said notice at the door of the council chamber, before the same is acted on by council; and before such franchise, license or right shall be granted. If granted, such franchise shall be passed upon favorably by a majority vote of the council at one regular monthly meeting of same. The application shall be considered by the mayor and council no later than 90 days after submission by the applicant as noted by the clerk receiving the application. 
(b)  Council may grant the franchise upon such terms and conditions as it may deem advisable and revoke same for a violation of such terms and conditions. 
(c)  Council may preliminarily approve an application pending a final agreement entered into under section 38-4-8. If no final agreement is reached such application approval shall be deemed void. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-5. - Standards for approval or refusal of franchise application. 
    The city shall manage the public rights-of-way by approving or denying franchise application and fees on a competitively neutral and non-discriminatory basis while publicly disclosing the compensation (franchise fee and administrative fee) required. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-6. - Franchise fee, application fee and administrative fee. 
(a)  The franchise fee shall be the greater of: (1) five percent of the applicant's annual gross revenue generated within the city; or, (2) a minimum fee paid to the city of $1,250.00 for each quarter this agreement is in effect; or, (3) a fee of $1.00 per linear foot of fiber optic telecommunications equipment located within the city but outside the downtown development district (as defined in the city's zoning ordinances) and a fee of $2.00 per linear foot of fiber optic telecommunications equipment located within the downtown development district within the city. All such payment of franchise fees shall be made on a quarterly basis and shall be remitted simultaneously with the submission of a quarterly franchise fee report to be forwarded to the city by mail not later than 30 days after the last day of each March, June, September, and December throughout the term of the franchise setting forth the gross revenue for the quarter ending on said last day. 
(b)  An application fee of $70.00 will be paid by the applicant at the time the application is delivered to the city. If a franchise is granted, the application fee will not be deemed a credit towards any other fees due by the grantee. If an application is denied, the application fee will not be refunded, except as required by law. 
(c)  An administrative fee shall be paid by the applicant at the time a final contract is executed. The fee shall reflect the actual costs of administering the franchise application and any resulting agreement. These costs shall be paid at the lowest hourly rate of the lowest paid employee or worker competent in the city's opinion to perform the work required to process, draft, and negotiate the application and agreement. Such fees will include but are not necessarily limited to document preparation, document processing, document review, field review, legal review, legal work regarding contract negotiation and drafting, contract execution, and any other city cost the city incurs as a result of the franchise application and award. 
(d)  The franchise fee, application fee and administrative fee are separate and apart from any additional fees required by the city as they relate to the activities of the grantee. The grantee remains responsible for securing all necessary permits prior to the start of construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade or removal of the facilities. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-7. - Audit and provision of audit information. 
(a)  Franchise fee payments subject to audit; remedy for underpayment. No acceptance of any franchise fee payment by the city shall be construed as an accord and satisfaction that the amount paid is in fact the correct amount or a release of any claim that the city may have for further or additional sums payable under a franchise and all amounts paid shall be subject to audit and recomputation by the city. Except as provided in subsection (b), the cost of the audit shall be borne by the city. 
(b)  Costs of audit. If, as a result of such audit or any other review, the city determines that grantee has underpaid its fees in any 12-month period by ten percent or more, then, in addition to making full payment of the relevant obligation, the grantee shall reimburse the city for all of the reasonable costs associated with the audit or review, including all reasonable out-of-pocket costs for attorneys, accountants, and other consultants. 
(c)  Payments not to be set off against taxes or vice versa. Payments made pursuant to this section and any other provision of this article are not a tax and are not in the nature of a tax and are in addition to any and all taxes of general applicability or other fees or charges (including any fees or charges which may be imposed on the grantee for the use of poles, conduits or similar facilities that may be owned or controlled by the city) which the grantee or any affiliated person shall be required to pay to the city. 
(d)  Interest on late payments. If any payment required by this article is not actually received by the city on or before the applicable date fixed in this article, the grantee shall pay interest thereon, from the due date to the date paid at a rate of one percent per month, for the period of delinquency. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-8. - Franchise agreement. 
    Each grantee shall enter into an agreement with the city which is consistent with the terms of this article. Each franchise agreement granted under this article shall be personal to the grantee and the terms of each franchise agreement may vary. The mere granting of a franchise agreement by the city in no way relieves the grantee of its responsibility to secure all permits necessary, prior to construction, for the operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade or removal of the facilities. The department of community services will administer each franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-9. - Duration of franchise. 
    Franchise agreements that extend beyond a calendar year shall comply with O.C.G.A. § 36-60-13. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-10. - Renewal of franchise. 
    Sixty days prior to the expiration of the agreement term, the grantee may apply for the renewal of this authorization. The city reserves the right to grant or deny such renewal. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-11. - Rights personal. 
(a)  The rights granted by this article to the grantee are personal to the grantee (as owned and controlled on the effective date of this article) and shall not be assigned, sold, pledged, leased, sublet, mortgaged or transferred, directly or indirectly, without the prior written consent of the city. 
(b)  It is not the intention of this article nor any subsequent agreement to grant any property right whatsoever to grantee. Further, grantee is required to contractually relinquish any claimed easement right within the city's municipal right-of-way. If any facility is placed by grantee outside of the city's right-of-way and such right-of-way is later expanded to include the grantee's facility, upon the city's request, such facility shall be removed or relocated at grantee's full and sole expense. The grantee, under contract and for the express consideration of the use of the city's right-of-way shall waive any and all claim for reimbursement for any costs for any removed or relocated facility and for any claim of any easement or other property right in the public right-of-way or expanded public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-12. - Inspections provisions of construction information. 
    The city shall inspect the activities of the grantee within the right-of-way including inspection of construction procedures and relocation of facilities and may require information necessary to perform an inspection including, but not limited to the information required under subsections 38-4-13(e) and (f). Such information shall include descriptions of how the grantee's facilities fit into the affected rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-13. - Construction practices. 
(a)  No grantee shall commence any construction, operation, maintenance, repair or upgrading of a franchise, or any part thereof, without having first secured the necessary permits from the city or other required public agencies having jurisdiction over the work to be performed. 
(b)  In those areas of the city where transmission or distribution facilities of all the public utilities providing telephone and electric power service are underground, the grantee likewise shall construct, operate and maintain its transmission and distribution facilities therein underground. 
(c)  In those areas of the city where a grantee's cables or facilities are located on the above-ground transmission or distribution facilities of the public utility providing telephone, electric power, or other service, and in the event that the facilities of such public utilities subsequently are placed underground, then the grantee likewise shall construct, operate and maintain its transmission and distribution facilities underground, at grantee's cost, provided that grantee may request a waiver, in writing, of the requirement for underground placement where such underground placement would be technologically unfeasible. Certain of grantee's equipment, such as pedestals, amplifiers and power supplies, which normally are placed aboveground, may continue to remain in above-ground closures. 
(d)  If the grades, lines, or right-of-way of any street within the service area are changed at any time during the term of a franchise, then the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense and upon the request of the city, protect or promptly alter or relocate the facilities or any part thereof, so as to conform with such new grades, lines, or rights-of-way. In the event that the grantee refuses or neglects to so protect, alter, or relocate all or part of the facilities, the city shall have the right to break through, remove, alter, or relocate all or any part of the facilities without any liability to the city and the grantee shall pay to the city all costs incurred in connection with such breaking through, removal, alternation, or relocation. 
(e)  Prior to construction a final location plan shall be submitted for approval by the inspection department, and the inspection department shall be authorized to permit or to require an alternate location for the proposed facilities within the public right-of-way to avoid conflict with other permitted uses or to establish an appropriate width from curb for placement of conduit for the use proposed. The city also reserves the right to inspect the installation and maintenance of grantee's facilities in or on the city's property. 
(f)  The grantee shall provide as-built drawings, acceptable to the city detailing the number and location of facilities installed pursuant to this article. The number and location of facilities may be reasonably regulated as set forth in this chapter. 
(g)  The grantee shall give the city 30 days advance written notice requesting any additional use of right-of-way and shall abide by any permitting requirements as specified by city ordinances. 
(h)  In connection with the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade, or removal of the facilities the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, protect any and all existing structures belonging to the city and all designated landmarks. The grantee agrees that it shall be liable, at its own cost and expense, to replace or repair and restore to its previous serviceable condition, in a manner as may be specified by the city, any street or any municipal structure involved in the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade or removal of the facilities that may become disturbed or damaged as a result of any work thereon by or on behalf of the grantee. 
(i)  In connection with the construction, operation, maintenance, repair, upgrade, or removal of the facility, the grantee shall not obstruct the streets, railways, passenger travel, river navigation, or other traffic to, from, or within the public rights-of-way without prior consent of the city and any other appropriate authorities. All such work shall be performed so as to cause minimal interference with users of the streets and adjoining property owners. 
(j)  The grantee shall, upon prior written notice by the city or any person holding a permit to move any structure, temporarily move its wires to permit the moving of said structure. The grantee may impose a reasonable charge on any person other than the city for any such movement of its wires. However, imposition of such a charge shall not be deemed to constitute an easement benefiting grantee. 
(k)  In case of a grantee's disturbance of pavement, sidewalks, driveways or other surfaces, the grantee shall, at its sole expense, replace and restore such surfaces, in as good a condition as before such work was commenced and in accordance with city standards. 
(l)  Erection, removal, and common uses of poles. 
(1)  No poles or other wire-holding structures shall be erected by the grantee without first having entered into a pole attachment agreement with the city. However, no location of any pole or wire-holding structure of the grantee shall be vested interest and such poles or structures shall be removed or modified by the grantee at its own expense whenever the council determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. 
(2)  Where poles or other wire-holding structures already existing for use in serving the city are available for use by the grantee on reasonable terms the council may require the grantee to use such poles and structures. If a grantee believes the terms with a private supplier to be unreasonable, it may apply, in writing, to the city for a waiver of this requirement. 
(3)  Poles in public right-of-way shall be removed or relocated at the sole expense of grantee at the request of the city when, in the city's sole discretion, removal or relocation is deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-14. - Insurance. 
(a)  Liability insurance. Throughout the term of any franchise, the grantee shall, at its own cost and expense, maintain a liability insurance policy or policies in a form acceptable to the city, and approved by the city attorney. The grantee shall furnish, at least annually, to the city certificates of insurance for all policies required by this article and the franchise. Each such liability insurance policy shall contain the following, or equivalent, endorsement: "It is hereby understood and agreed that this policy may not be canceled nor the intention not to renew be stated until sixty (60) days after receipt by the city, by registered mail, of a written notice of such intent to cancel or not to renew." Not later than 30 days prior to cancellation of required insurance, the grantee shall obtain and furnish to the city replacement insurance policies in a form reasonably acceptable to the city. 
(b)  Increase insurance coverage. In the event of any changed circumstances following the effective date, the city may, after consulting with the grantee, alter the minimum limitation of the liability insurance policy or policies required in this section. 
(c)  Liability not limited. The legal liability of the company and any affiliated person to the city and any person for any of the matters which are the subject of the liability insurance policies required by this section, including, without limitation, the grantee indemnification obligations set forth in this article shall not be limited by such insurance policies nor by the recovery of any amounts thereunder, except to the extent necessary to avoid duplicative recovery from or payment by the grantee. 
(d)  Self insurance. In lieu of purchasing one or more commercial insurance policies, grantee may provide for the above-referenced types and amounts of insurance through self-insurance, subject to approval of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-15. - Letter of credit. 
(a)  Within ten days after formal award of a franchise, the grantee shall deposit with the city a letter of credit from a financial institution in the amount of $10,000.00. The form and content of such letter of credit shall be approved by the city attorney. The letter of credit shall be used to insure the faithful performance by the grantee of all provisions of a franchise; and compliance with all orders, permits and directives of any agency, commission, board, department, division or office of the city having jurisdiction over its acts or defaults under the franchise, and the payment by the grantee of any claims, liens and taxes due the city which arise by reason of the construction, operation or maintenance of the system. 
(b)  The letter of credit shall be maintained at $10,000.00 during the entire term of the franchise, even if amounts have to be withdrawn pursuant to subsections (a) or (c) of this section. 
(c)  If the grantee fails to pay to the city any compensation within the time fixed herein; or fails to repay the city within ten days, for underpayments, any damages, costs or expenses which the city is compelled to pay by reason of any act or default of the grantee in connection with this franchise; or, fails, after three days' notice of such failure by the grantee to comply with any provision of the franchise which the city reasonably determines can be remedied by demand on the letter of credit, the council may immediately request payment of the amount thereof, with interest, calculated at the rate of one percent per month, from the date of delinquency, and any penalties, from the letter of credit. Upon such request for payment, the city shall notify the grantee of the amount and date thereof. 
(d)  Enforcement of this article with respect to the letter of credit is in addition to all other rights of the city, authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such letter of credit shall affect any other right the city may have. 
(e)  The letter of credit shall contain the following, or equivalent, endorsement: 
"It is hereby understood and agreed that this letter of credit shall not be canceled by the surety nor the intention not to renew be stated by the surety until sixty (60) days after receipt by the City of Hapeville, Georgia, Mayor and Council, by registered mail, of a written notice of such intention to cancel or not to renew." 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-16. - Performance bond. 
(a)  Within 30 days after the award of a franchise, the grantee shall file with the city a performance bond in the amount of $100,000.00 in favor of the city. This bond shall be approved by the city attorney and shall be maintained throughout the construction or upgrade of the entire facility or until such time as the city may require. 
(b)  In the event the grantee fails to comply with any law, ordinance or regulation governing the franchise, or fails to well and truly observe, fulfill and perform each term and condition of the franchise, there shall be recoverable, jointly and severally, from the principal and surety of the bond, any damages or loss suffered by the city as a result, including the full amount of any compensation, indemnification, or cost of removal or abandonment of any property of the grantee, plus a reasonable allowance for attorney's fees, up to the full amount of the bond. This section shall be an additional remedy for any and all violations outlined in section 38-4-18. 
(c)  The city may, upon completion of construction or upgrade of the grantee, waive or reduce the requirement of the grantee to maintain said bond. However, the city may require that a performance bond be posted by the grantee for any construction subsequent to the completion of the work in the right-of-way, in a reasonable amount and upon such terms as determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-17. - Abandonment or removal of franchise property. 
(a)  In the event that the use of any property of grantee within the right-of-way or a portion thereof is discontinued for a continuous period of six months, grantee shall be deemed to have abandoned that franchise property. 
(b)  The city, upon such terms as it may impose, may give grantee permission to abandon, without removing, any grantee property or equipment under the franchise. Unless such permission is granted or unless otherwise provided in this article, the grantee shall remove all abandoned above-ground facilities and equipment upon receipt of written notice from the city and shall restore any affected city property to its former state at the time such facilities and equipment were installed, so as not to impair its usefulness. In removing its plant, structures and equipment, grantee shall refill, at its own expense, any excavation that shall be made by it and shall leave all public ways and places in as good condition as that prevailing prior to such removal without materially interfering with any electrical or telephone cable or other utility wires, poles or attachments. The city shall have the right to inspect and approve the condition of the public ways, public places, cables, wires, attachments and poles prior to and after removal. The liability, indemnity and insurance provisions of this article and any security fund provided in the franchise shall continue in full force and effect during the period of removal and until full compliance by grantee with the terms and conditions of this section. 
(c)  At the expiration of the term for which the franchise is granted, or upon abandonment as defined above or upon its revocation or earlier expiration, as provided for herein, in any such case without renewal, extension or transfer, the city shall have the right to require grantee to remove, at its own expense, all above-ground portions of its facilities from all streets and public ways within the city within a reasonable period of time, which shall not be less than 180 days. 
(d)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this article, the grantee may abandon any underground franchise property in place so long as it does not, in the city's sole discretion, materially interfere with the use of the street or public rights-of-way in which such property is located or with the use thereof by any public utility or other cable grantee. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-18. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    Penalty provisions applicable to zoning as provided by section 93-24-6 of the zoning ordinance of the city, in existence before the adoption of this article shall be and are herein readopted and made applicable to this article as if fully set out herein. Further, action taken by the city under the penalty provisions of section 93-24-6 of this Code shall not bar the city from taking any civil action against a party violating this article which may include a demand for reimbursement of attorney's fees and any other fee expended by the city in enforcing the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-19. - Relationship to other ordinances and franchises. 
    This article shall not supersede nor repeal article 3 of this same chapter, CATV Franchises, nor chapter 38, article 2, of this Code. If it is determined that this article and the said chapters conflict, the more restrictive provision shall apply except in the area of CATV Franchises (governed by chapter 38, article 3) and the siting of telecommunications towers and antennas (governed by chapter 38, article 2). 
    Furthermore, this article shall not be deemed to repeal any franchise agreement duly approved and executed before the effective date of this chapter. Furthermore, this provision shall not be deemed to in any way to allow any attempt by the mayor and council to contractually or otherwise limit their police powers. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Sec. 38-4-20. - Revocation. 
    If the grantee fails to comply with any of the terms and conditions of this article, then the city may, in addition to the other penalties herein, revoke the authorization granted herein. The city shall notify the grantee of its failure to comply and give grantee 30 days to correct such default before revocation. The notice required hereunder shall not be required for issuance of a citation for a violation of this article as set out in section 38-4-17 without invoking the revocation provisions hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2002-03, § 2, 5-7-2002) 
Chapter 41 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES 
ARTICLE 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 41-1-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted by reference. 
    Pursuant O.C.G.A. title 40, chapter 6, sections 40-6-372 through 40-6-376, sections 40-6-1 through 40-6-397 of that chapter, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A § 40-1-1, as hereafter amended, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited herein. 
(Code 1981, § 10-1-1; Ord. No. 91-5, 2-5-1991) 
Sec. 41-1-2. - Temporary traffic regulations. 
    In cases where traffic upon the streets of the city may become congested upon occasions of parades, at theaters and other public assemblages where large numbers of vehicles are assembled, the police may make temporary rules directing and regulating the traffic in these congested districts, and any person who, after being warned of the temporary traffic regulations, shall violate them shall be liable therefor as for other violations of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 10-1-2) 
Sec. 41-1-3. - Vehicle cover required. 
    No person shall operate or load any vehicle on the public streets and roads of this city unless the vehicle is constructed, loaded and securely covered so as to prevent any of its load from dropping, escaping or shifting in such a manner as to create a safety hazard or in such a manner so as to litter the streets and roads of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 10-1-3) 
Sec. 41-1-4. - Police committee; powers and duties generally. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the police committee, and to this end it shall have the authority within the limits of the funds at its disposal, to carry on educational activities in traffic matters, to supervise the publication of traffic reports, to receive suggestions and complaints having to do with traffic matters and to recommend to the mayor and council and to the city traffic engineer and other city officials ways and means for improving traffic conditions and the administration and enforcement of traffic regulations. 
(b)  No ordinance providing for the control of traffic on the streets of the city shall be enacted by the mayor and council until after such proposed ordinance shall have been submitted to the police chief and also to the police committee, and their several recommendations received thereon. All proposed traffic ordinances referred by the mayor and council to the police committee shall be reported back to the mayor and council within 30 days after such reference with its recommendation, otherwise the mayor and council may act on such proposed ordinance without the recommendation of the police committee. 
(Code 1959, § 20-2; Code 1981, § 10-1-4) 
Sec. 41-1-5. - Designation of noncommercial traffic streets. 
(a)  In order to improve traffic conditions and to restrict the flow of certain types of traffic in certain areas, the police committee or the mayor and council is hereby authorized and empowered to designate certain streets and areas within the city as restricted to noncommercial traffic by the posting of appropriate signs sufficiently conspicuous to be observed by motorists. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a commercial or commercial-type motor vehicle on any streets designated "no commercial traffic." 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed, however, as preventing proper commercial vehicles having definite business in a particular restricted area of the city from entering such area for purposes of making deliveries or pickups, or otherwise servicing the property of any resident of such area; the purpose of this section being to prevent the use of certain city streets by commercial vehicles passing through en route to other destinations. 
(Code 1959, § 20-3; Code 1981, § 10-1-5) 
Sec. 41-1-6. - Designation of traffic engineer; responsibilities. 
(a)  The chief of police is designated as city traffic engineer. 
(b)  The traffic engineer shall be responsible for conducting engineering analyses of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures, conducting engineering investigation of traffic conditions and cooperating with other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and carrying out the additional powers and duties imposed by this chapter and other ordinances of the city. 
(c)  The city engineer or other designated person shall install and maintain at the direction of the traffic engineer all traffic control signals, signs and markings. 
(Code 1981, § 10-1-6) 
Sec. 41-1-7. - Through commercial traffic prohibited on certain streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for through commercial traffic to be operated upon the following designated streets: 
(1)  Whitney Avenue from North Avenue to South Central Avenue; 
(2)  Virginia Place from Virginia Avenue to Whitney Avenue; 
(3)  Jonesboro Road from Mount Zion Road to King Arnold Street; 
(4)  North Avenue from Dogwood Drive to Sylvan Road; 
(5)  Myrtle Street from Central Avenue to North Avenue; 
(6)  Sunset Avenue; and 
(7)  Such other streets as may from time to time be posted. 
(Code 1959, § 20-21; Code 1981, § 10-1-7) 
Sec. 41-1-8. - Large vehicle traffic prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any large vehicle, in excess of 10,000 pounds gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR), on the following streets: 
(1)  North Central Avenue from Sylvan Road to Dogwood Drive. 
(2)  The entirety of South Central Avenue. 
(3)  The entirety of King Arnold Street. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the operation of: 
(1)  Large vehicles making deliveries of people or property to areas, homes, or businesses accessible only by routes including the roads described herein; or 
(2)  Large vehicles by the owner or operator of such vehicle while on his or her way to his or her residence. 
(3)  Recreational vehicles by the owner or operator of such vehicle while on his or her way to his or her residence. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section: 
(1)  The term "large vehicle" shall mean tractors, trailers, cabs, trucks, vehicle carriers, tow trucks, towing vehicles, and truck cabs. 
(2)  The term "recreational vehicles" shall mean vehicles that are used primarily for recreational purposes, are not used primarily for transportation, and are not used for commercial purposes. 
(Ord. No. 2001-09, § 1, 5-1-2001) 
Sec. 41-1-9. - Vehicle weight limit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle including tractors and trailers upon any street in any residential area whenever the total weight of the vehicle and its load exceeds ten tons. 
(Code 1959, § 20-22; Code 1981, § 10-1-8) 
Sec. 41-1-10. - Blocking crossings by railroad trains. 
    It shall be unlawful for the directing officer or the operator of any railroad train to direct the operation of or to operate the same in such a manner as to prevent the use of any street for purposes of travel for a period of time longer than five minutes, except that this provision shall not apply to trains or cars in motion other than those engaged in switching. 
(Code 1959, § 20-28; Code 1981, § 10-1-9) 
Sec. 41-1-11. - Vegetation; creation of traffic hazard, abatement procedure. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for owners of property in the city to permit shrubbery or other vegetation to grow or to accumulate to a height of more than three feet within seven feet of the curb of any public street, road or alley when, in the opinion of the police chief or the police committee, or both, the same shall constitute a menace or a hazard to traffic. 
(b)  Upon notification by the police chief or the chairman of the police committee, or the designated representative of either, the owner of any property held to be in violation of the foregoing will, within three days after such notification, remedy the defective condition pointed out or cited to him in the notification according to instructions received. 
(c)  If, in the opinion of the property owner, the notice under this section by the police chief, chairman of the police committee or their designated representative seems unreasonable, unfair or would work an unnecessary hardship upon him, the property owner may, at his request, be given the right to appear before the mayor and council and state his case before any further action is taken against him, and the decision of the mayor and council shall be final and binding upon all concerned. 
(d)  Any person who violates the provisions of this section by failing within three days following notification to comply therewith shall be brought to trial in the municipal court, and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this Code. 
(Code 1959, §§ 20-29, 20-30; Code 1981, §§ 10-1-10, 10-1-11) 
Sec. 41-1-12. - Interference with vehicular traffic by airplanes, helicopters, etc. 
    It shall be unlawful for any airplane, helicopter or any other flying machine, intended to be propelled through the air, to be propelled, driven, dragged, pulled or pushed across any city street within the city, it being the intent of this section that no interference with vehicular traffic shall be permitted. 
(Code 1959, § 14.1; Code 1981, § 10-1-12) 
Sec. 41-1-13. - Proof of insurance required. 
    The Georgia Motor Vehicle Accident Reparations Act, Georgia Laws 1974, p. 113, as thereafter amended and in particular Georgia Laws 1978, p. 1369, are hereby adopted by reference and made part of this Code as if set out in full, therefore it shall be unlawful to operate a motor vehicle within the city without liability insurance and proof thereof. 
(Ord. No. 80-7, 7-10-1980; Code 1981, § 10-1-13) 
ARTICLE 2. - VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 41-2-1. - Traffic violations bureau; creation; schedule of fines to be prepared. 
(a)  The judge of the municipal court shall establish a traffic violations bureau to assist the court with the clerical work of traffic cases. The bureau shall be in charge of those persons and shall be open at those hours as the judge may designate. 
(b)  The judge who hears traffic cases shall designate the specified offense under this chapter or traffic ordinances of the city and applicable state traffic laws in respect to which payments of fines may be accepted by the traffic violations bureau in satisfaction thereof, and shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided those fines are within the limits declared by law or ordinance, and shall further specify what number of offenses shall require appearance before the municipal court. 
(c)  When fines are paid to the traffic violations bureau as provided herein, no court costs shall be assessed or collected. 
(Code 1959, § 20-160; Code 1981, § 10-1-111) 
Sec. 41-2-2. - Same; duties. 
    The following duties are hereby imposed upon the traffic violations bureau in reference to traffic offenses: 
(1)  It shall accept designated fines, issue receipts and represent in court those violators as are permitted and desire to plead guilty, waive court appearance and give power of attorney. 
(2)  It shall receive and issue receipts for cash bail from the persons who must or wish to be heard in court, enter the time of their appearance on the court docket and notify the arresting officer and witnesses, if any, to be present. 
(3)  It shall keep an easily accessible record of all violations of which each person has been guilty during the preceding 12 months, whether guilt was established in court or in the traffic violations bureau. 
(Code 1959, § 20-161; Code 1981, § 10-1-112) 
Sec. 41-2-3. - Same; records and reports. 
    The traffic violations bureau shall keep any records and make any reports as the mayor and council may from time to time require. 
(Code 1959, § 20-162; Code 1981, § 10-1-113) 
Sec. 41-2-4. - Same; procedure. 
    The traffic violations bureau shall follow any procedure as may be prescribed by this chapter or other traffic ordinances of the city or as may be required by any laws of the state. 
(Code 1959, § 20-163; Code 1981, § 10-1-114) 
Sec. 41-2-5. - Same; payment of fines thereto. 
(a)  Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may be made to the traffic violations bureau shall have the option of paying the fine within the time specified in the notice of arrest to the officer in charge at the city police station upon entering a plea of guilty and upon waiving appearance in court; or may have the option of depositing required lawful bail and upon a plea of not guilty shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. 
(b)  The payment of a fine to the officer on duty shall be deemed an acknowledgement of conviction of the alleged offense, and the officer upon accepting the prescribed fine shall issue a receipt to the violator acknowledging the payment thereof. 
(Code 1959, § 20-164; Code 1981, § 10-1-115) 
Sec. 41-2-6. - Procedure upon arrest; issuance of notice to appear. 
    Except when authorized or directed under state law immediately to take a person arrested for a violation of any of the traffic laws before the municipal court, any police officer, upon making an arrest for violation of the state traffic laws, this chapter or other traffic ordinance of the city, shall take the name, address and number of the motor vehicle involved and shall issue to him in writing on a form provided by the city a notice to answer to the charge against him at a place and time to be specified in the notice. The officer, upon receiving the written promise of the alleged violator to answer as specified in the notice, may release that person from custody. 
(Code 1959, § 20-172; Code 1981, § 10-1-116) 
Sec. 41-2-7. - Liability of owner for parking violation; equally with operator. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in his name to stand or park in any street in violation of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city regulating the parking of vehicles. Such person shall be equally liable with the operator for any violation and in addition thereto may have his vehicle impounded, as provided in section 41-7-2. 
(Code 1959, § 20-173; Code 1981, § 10-1-117) 
Sec. 41-2-8. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. 
(a)  In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the standing or parking of a vehicle proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked in violation of any law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of the parking the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked or placed that vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, the violation occurred. 
(b)  The foregoing stated presumption shall apply only when the procedure as prescribed in sections 41-2-9 and 41-2-11 has been followed. 
(Code 1959, § 20-174; Code 1981, § 10-1-118) 
Sec. 41-2-9. - Affixing notice to illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by this chapter or other ordinance of the city or by state law, the officer finding the vehicle shall take its registration number and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user, and shall conspicuously affix to the vehicle a notice in writing, on a form provided by the city, for the driver to answer to the charge against him at the time and place specified in the notice. 
(Code 1959, § 20-175; Code 1981, § 10-1-119) 
Sec. 41-2-10. - Failure to appear after giving written promise. 
    Any person who violates his written promise to appear given to an officer upon an arrest for any traffic violation is guilty of an offense regardless of the disposition of the charge on which he was originally arrested. 
(Code 1959, § 20-176; Code 1981, § 10-1-120) 
Sec. 41-2-11. - Failure to comply with notice affixed to vehicle. 
    If a violator of the restrictions on stopping, standing or parking under this chapter or other traffic laws or ordinances does not appear in response to a notice affixed to the vehicle, at the time and place specified, the judge shall send to the owner of the motor vehicle to which the notice was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that in the event the letter is disregarded for a period of five days from the date of the letter, a summons of arrest will be issued. 
(Code 1959, § 20-177; Code 1981, § 10-1-121) 
Sec. 41-2-12. - When summons for arrest to be issued. 
    In the event any person fails to comply with a notice given to that person or attached to a vehicle or fails to make appearance pursuant to a summons directing an appearance in the police department, or if any person fails or refuses to deposit bail as required and within the time permitted by ordinance, the judge shall forthwith secure and issue a summons for his arrest. 
(Code 1959, § 20-178; Code 1981, § 10-1-122) 
Sec. 41-2-13. - When warrant for arrest to be issued. 
    When it shall be made to appear to the judge that any person has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in the municipal court for trial and shall fail to appear at the time and place set forth in the copy of charges, it shall be the duty of the judge to forthwith issue a warrant for the arrest of such person and deliver same to the police chief. 
(Code 1959, § 20-179; Code 1981, § 10-1-123) 
Sec. 41-2-14. - Penalty for failure to appear when served with copy of charges. 
    Any person who has been lawfully served with a copy of charges to appear in the municipal court and shall fail to appear at the time and place indicated in the copy of charges shall be guilty of an offense and, upon conviction in the municipal court, shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of the Code. 
(Code 1959, § 20-180; Code 1981, § 10-1-124) 
Sec. 41-2-15. - Suspension or revocation of driver's license; duty of judge. 
    If, upon the trial of charges against any person charged with violating this chapter or any other ordinance of the city relating to traffic, the judge shall suspend or revoke the driver's license of the defendant, it shall be his duty immediately to take up and transmit the driver's license involved to the police chief and to notify the police chief of the length of the suspension or the revocation and to provide the police chief with such information as will enable him to identify the person whose driver's license has been suspended or revoked. 
(Code 1959, § 20-181; Code 1981, § 10-1-125) 
Sec. 41-2-16. - Signing recommendation to restore driver's license. 
    Any recommendation to restore a driver's license which has been suspended or revoked as provided in section 41-2-15 shall be signed by the judge who originally tried the case and suspended or revoked such license. 
(Code 1959, § 20-182; Code 1981, § 10-1-126) 
Sec. 41-2-17. - Modification of sentence. 
    No sentence imposed by the municipal court shall be modified in any particular except by the judge or person who originally tried the case. 
(Code 1959, § 20-183; Code 1981, § 10-1-127) 
Sec. 41-2-18. - Exceptions to sections 41-2-16 and 41-2-17. 
    The restrictions contained in sections 41-2-16 and 41-2-17 hereof, upon the authority of the judge to recommend the restoration of a driver's license which has been suspended or revoked or to modify the sentence of the court, shall not apply when the judge who originally tried the case is absent from the city for a period of more than five days or is absent from the office for such period on account of illness. 
(Code 1959, § 20-184; Code 1981, § 10-1-128) 
Sec. 41-2-19. - Disposition of fines and forfeitures. 
    All fines or forfeitures collected upon conviction or upon the forfeiture of bail of any person charged with a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or other traffic ordinance of the city shall be paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1959, § 20-185; Code 1981, § 10-1-129) 
Sec. 41-2-20. - General penalty. 
    Whenever in this chapter or in any other traffic ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this chapter or other ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of such provision of this chapter or any ordinance shall be punished as provided in section 1-1-8 of this Code. In case of continuing violations, each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense and may be punished as such. It shall be discretionary with the judge to punish any person convicted of violation of any provision of this chapter or any other traffic ordinances by ordering him to work on the public streets or public works of the city. In passing sentence of imprisonment upon persons, the judge, in his discretion, when from the age or sex of those convicted or other circumstances surrounding them, he shall deem it wise, may require any imprisonment to be served by incarceration at the police station and by labor in and about that station. 
(Code 1959, § 20-187; Code 1981, § 10-1-130) 
ARTICLE 3. - TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 41-3-1. - Authority to install. 
    Subject to the procedures set forth for the installation of speed humps set forth in section 41-3-8, the city traffic engineer shall cause to be placed and maintained traffic-control signs, signals, and devices when and as required under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city to make effective the provisions of this chapter and other traffic ordinances. Subject to the procedures set forth for the installation of speed humps set forth in section 41-3-8 the city traffic engineer may cause to be placed and maintained such additional traffic control devices as he or she shall deem necessary to regulate traffic under this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city or under state law, or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Code 1959, § 20-31; Code 1981, § 10-1-21; Ord. No. 2008-12, § 1, 9-2-2008) 
Sec. 41-3-2. - Manual and specifications. 
    Subject to the procedures set forth for the installation of speed humps set forth in section 41-3-8, all traffic-control devices shall conform to specifications in the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices adopted by the state transportation board.
